reviewText:
Preface:
It appears, Dancing Dragon Games, developed Deadly Sin as their first commercial release.  Deadly Sin II came shortly after. Their latest, steam available title, is Skyborn. If you play all three games, you will noticed that the underlying battle mechanic and misc. scripts have changed very little between the three. The largest change being the simplification of skill advancement, and the 'GUI' in the battle scene. But the crafting (augments), threat system, etc... All pretty much identical.

TL,DR version:
Skyborn isn't all that different from its predecessors Deadly Sin I & II, but it is different EXACTLY where it matters the most. I am referring to the story of course... If you've played the other two games and fought a single battle, you've played Skyborn's as well. While it  may look different, battles really aren't in any measurable sense.

However, Skyborn has a far superior story line.

While it has a few pacing issues that DS1 didn’t suffer (IMO), it is FAR better packaged, along with accompanying graphics and music. This game plays like an interactive movie... A 'B' movie with almost no budget, but respectable movie none the less. This strength outweighs its flaws to where I will recommend it, even to non RPG Maker enthusiasts.

Pro:

- The Intro is GREAT. (First hour or so)
The main character is well spoken, and has very HUMAN reactions (as opposed to typical JRPG tropes) to the nature of her circumstance. The camera movement, NPC introductions, and 'framing' of the events, that sweep you off into an adventure, are spot on. This is without a doubt the best written intro to ANY RPG Maker game to date. (IMO) It is a BIG reason why I recommend it.

- Unlike Deadly Sin, the maps are pretty & reasonably designed.
One of my biggest gripes with RPGMaker games is the haphazard nature of their maps... And while this developers previous games have been above average (in presentation) they were quite 'typical' in floor plan. Until Skyborn. Yes, it is still very linear, but there aren't nearly as many pointlessly long hallway dead ends, nor inexplicable road blocks.


Con:

- Difficulty Spikes.
Ugh... UGH!! ARGHAHH!!!!!
Why is this so difficult for RPG Maker developers to get even SLIGHLY balanced?!?
(Read my Deadly Sin review if you want to read my small rant)

- One collection side quest - time sink.
A flower collecting side quest... /sigh
The reward wasn't even worth it... Not in the slightest.

- This is Deadly Sin, re-skinned with a new story...
If it wasn't such an improvement over the previous titles, this would have counted for more, and likely caused me to not recommend the game... It screams laziness.  It wouldn't be so bad if the game was LONGER and BETTER BALANCED for its complete repeat of the guts of the DS titles. But it's NOT. It actually feels shorter... though that may simply be my bias.
(Yes I realize that they made the transition to a newer RPG Maker tool set... It's still no excuse.)


Wrap Up:
If you liked the Deadly Sin series. Buy this one without hesitation. Even at the MSRP. It was that enjoyable for me.

However, if you are NOT a fan of RPG Maker games... This is worth the discounted price IMO. As long as you understand you are not buying a balanced game with satisfying combat. You are buying an interactive novel with a reasonably well done story.

That also happens to have JRPG levels of grind.

reviewText: I have played this game before the steam version. The battle gameplay is basically the default of RPG Maker (if it's not re-scripted a bit). reviewText:
Surprisingly good RPGmaker game. Linear gameplay (you can't go back to certain areas), good story and possibly a low amount of combat (you can avoid monsters), paired with a high amount of experience gain makes leveling and clearing the game rather easy.

However, there is a arena mode that will offer some challenge later on (haven't tried it yet). The atmosphere and game world is beliavable and unique and the encounters differ from location to location. Music is good and mostly fitting. I wish I could resize the window to a size I wanted through the game menu - this isn't possible right now.

There are some small inaccuracies and glitches in the game. For example, an ability that's supposed to slow enemy STR and Speed by 50%, does damage for 50% of their current hp instead. Abilities could use more balance; you stop getting abilities at certain points in the game, so leveling doesn't really do much. The enemies can be very unbalanced, being easy to kill at first and then they start doing insane damage, 1 hitting some members of your party (when I went to the mine for the second time, I got hit for 30k when I had 2k hp).

The end boss is incredibly unbalanced, often almost 1 hitting my whole team and keeps doing that until i run out of mana or get critically hit. very frustrating ; i have teh best gear, augments and everything but it simply hits for too much .. even though I did skip doing colosseum and getting full card set, it should be doable as I followed the story right.

I'd say the game is worth at least 5€ tho.

8/10

As an RPG Gamer, I would say that after clearing this game, it was really enjoyable and what shock me the most is that this is created by RPGMaker.

Firstly, I would say about the balance boss fight which is mostly not found in RPG games(However, some of the boss are requires correct skills to defeat) and the mobs does not respawn. Thus, the max level i reached is 65. The sidequest are easy to clear and the best thing in this game is that each character has different roles unlike some of the RPG I played which have same roles which is really pointless.

Secondly, Some of the area in the game is confusing(contains warp) which makes me walk 1-2 rounds to remember the path to walk. To clear the spade quest(13 cards, it would require time to lurk around the map and especially map that warp it would really takes time and hunting treasure box sure is interesting)

Thirdly, I would just say that this is an appealing RPG game.

This is one of the best RPG maker games I've played to date, easily up there with To the Moon. It is a simple RPG that reminds me of the days of old; fun, easy to play, simple, yet filled with depth. The story may seem cliche at first, but is actually very well written and full of surprises. I highly recommend, 10/10.

It's a short rpg, it's got the basic turn based rpg battle. equipmentz is intresting and stories nut too bad either,\ngame did feel a little to easy i barely grinded but killed most enemies in 1 turn. Also it does feel like it costs a little bit too much.

What can I say about Skyborn.  It's a great JRPG made on RPG Maker.  As you can probably tell by the pictures, it is a steampunk style game.  The combat system feels great, and the game has a pretty decent story.  The game is pretty easy though so if you are looking for something challenging, I would look elsewhere.  There's a ton of quests to keep you busy, with a find all the things laying around the map" quest to keep you busy as well.  If you are looking for a casual rpg where you can just faceroll and still enjoy the game

As a really big fan of old RPG's and very much the FF series I must say that this indie game is really good for so many reasons. Skyborn is a short but well executed RPG. It is an RPGMaker game, but the creativity present in this game allows it to shine despite the limitations of the engine.

Unlike many RPGs, Skyborn has zero random encounters. You encounter enemies by running into an enemy sprite on the map. The downside of this system is that enemies do not respawn, limiting resources somewhat. The lack of spawning enemies might be a limitation of RPGMaker, but Skyborn is so well polished that I can't even call this a limitation.

As a result of the enemy encounter system, there is effectively no gringind. Though this did shorten the game considerably, it kept it very much to the point. Leveling does very little to make things easier. Rather, what you do with your items, skills and equipment will ultimately determine the outcome of every encounter.

During battle, the order in which each character may act (both allies and enemies) is displayed, allowing for deeper levels of strategy. The display wasn't immediately self-explanatory, but I couldn't help but get excited once I realized what it was. A character's speed reflects the number of times they can act before another character. Speed is a critical factor in Skyborn. It can be increased with some careful planning, but will fall drastically if a character is loaded up with equipment that is heavier than they can handle.

The graphics are pleasant to look at, and are of a very high quality for a retro 2D RPG. If you don't believe me, check out the screenshots for this game. There's no background graphics for battles (the map graphics are darkened considerably), but this ironically kept me more immersed in the battle itself. The environments are varied and gameplay elements encourage exploring. Even when it's detrimental, I never go straight for the boss. I can't help myself.

The story is decent, well executed, and draws you in. On the down side, it is a bit short, and nothing surprising happens. Optional quests are also somewhat lacking due to the game's length, but most are quite fun and challenging.

There is an optional super-boss very near the end of the game. If you have any plans on beating it, you'll probably want to keep a save file before the point of no return, so you can experiment with equipment and other such things.

Skyborn is a much more casual RPG experience than I'm used to. But there are plenty of other casual RPGs that are phenomenal (Chrono Trigger and Earthbound to name a few). Skyborn isn't among the best RPGs I've played, but it is a clean, well polished game with its own unique charm.
Skyborn is a brilliant game set in a fantasy world its soundtrack is amazing and the plot sucks you in if you are in for a good 6-10 hours of adventure i highly reccomend it

reviewText: Bringing to mind memories of days past, Skyborn is a turn-based Role-Playing Game that recalls famous titles from the mid-90s.\nDrawing inspiration from games that made the JRPG genre famous, such as Chrono Trigger, various Final Fantasy titles, and lesser-known gems like RoboTrek, Skyborn weaves a story that leaves those that play it wanting more, even after the end. A memorable cast of characters and well-written interactions, along with a cohesive story and a refreshing plot twist, really make Skyborn a title that no Turn-based RPG fan should go without.\nThough I enjoyed the game immensely, I did notice a couple of issues that prevent me from giving this game a full 10/10. A couple of characters had a few cliche traits that detracted a little from my overall experience. Though the character development fixes this, it comes a little too late to be completely redeemable. An overall dearth of sidequests, outside of one or two go here
recommended: come talk to me" fetch missions

reviewText: Great classic RPG game reminds me of the ones i used to play on the gameboy advance back in the day :D
A good game to play at night after work when you need to relax for a bit.  Great storyline.

This game started very strong for me. I fell in love with the characters and the plot was pretty good and got me ready to see what adventures the game had in store for me.
However, by the addition of the fith party member it started to feel... rushed. Characters started to contridict themselves and it felt a bit flat. The whole story was like a beginners arc to a much larger story but pushed itself straight into SURPRISE this is the end of the world as we know it and you have to save it.
I wouldn't say that it should have been much longer, but for me it felt a bit lacking.

The battle system was unique but I found it a little frustrating when a party memeber is a dedicated healer and enemies can hardly do %20 of a member's HP. Also, you don't really HAVE to do much battling if you like to explore maps because if you do you will find glowing orbs of exp that will keep you up to speed with most bosses. I copletely ignored my equipment until the end of the game and still beat the final boss in under 10 minutes. (who was only announced right before his appearance) kinda underwhelming.

Overall
I did enjoy the first %75 of the game and felt like buying it on sale was not a waste of time or money. I would suggest it to others if they could get passed a rushed ending and simple battle mechanic.
I'm not a big fan of Indie games, but I was surprised when I played this game in a good way obviously. 100% recommend :)

If you have an itch to play a simple RPGMaker game this is probably your best option on Steam.

My only problems with the game were the amount of enemies and the fact that in certain levels you can get lost pretty easily with no mini-map to help you in that sort situation.

Of course I should note that you don't have to fight every enemy, avoiding them is a choice you can freely make.

I really enjoyed the story and art in this short fantasy steampunk adventure. You can see monster encounters coming so no surprises while walking around, and although there is the expected maze element in some of the levels which can be annoying it's nothing too daunting and there aren't too many levels to get lost in. I expect that one day I'll play the game again the way I would read a good novel again.

reviewText: Skyborn was really fun.  In a lot of ways, I guess it seemed like another RPGMaker game
date:
but the characters are very likeable, the story is compelling, and gameplay was well-paced.  It really didn't take long for me to be hooked on the game.

You have to understand that I rarely see a game all the way to the end, even a ~6-hour game like Skyborn.  My attention span runs out... but not this time.  I cared about the characters and really wanted to find out what happened to their story.

PROS

Extremely likeable characters -- nearly every time a new character joined the party, I was immediately drawn to his or her unique personality.

Interesting (though short) story.

Nice graphics... RPGMaker style, of course, but a really nice example of what that platform can do.

No time wasted on tedious, pointless questing.

No grinding.

CONS

Combat was... a little one-note.  There wasn't a lot of depth to it.

Short game. (Maybe a pro for some folks...)

No support for Steam Overlay features in Windows.

Er... that's mostly it.  I didn't have a lot of complaints about the game. :P

reviewText: Skyborn, a RPG Maker title with a steampunk setting tells an interesting tale of a spunky female mechanic named Claret who, after a chain of events becomes embroiled in an rebellion against a Winged Race of beings simply known as The Skyborn. Skyborn offers a standard RPG experience but with some neat features, such as the ability to forge more powerful weapons and armor and adding augments to further enchance equipment. These Augmentations can either make you more physically imposing, a more powerful spell caster or a more nimble character overall. So there is a small element of battle preparation and strategy when forging and augmenting your party's equipment.\n\nVisually it's much like many RPG Maker and 16-Bit era RPGs of it's day though some of the steampunk aspects stand out a little for me. Music and sounds are pretty good as well, with some haunting melodies and catchy battle themes, though the sounds used are standard RPG Maker stock noises. Battles play out like many J-RPGs in that each character and enemy take their turn with a choice of physical attack, special skill, or defending. Though I've only started playing this game I highly recommend giving it a try, especially if you are a fan of RPGs in general, you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
Eh....

It's got a compelling story. It's got flashy graphics. Memorable characters. All of that good stuff.

It's just not fun to play. I don't enjoy sitting through half-hours of uncontrollable cut-scenery. I don't enjoy the battle system one bit.

There are some really, really cool features, such as the forge, and the skill-set design is really good for the battle system, but these aren't enough to make me enjoy the game. I just don't have fun while I'm playing it. I'd almost rather read the story as a book.

Oh yeah, and those stupid pop-up portraits that take up the entire freakin' screne when anyone talks.

It's wonderfully produced, just not my cup of tea. I can honestly say that I tried very hard to enjoy the game, and just couldn't.

reviewText: I was in the mood for some steampunk game and noticed I had this (I'm assuming from some humble bundle). Thought I'd turn it on, play a few minutes and go meh. To my surprise I was enjoying it. Story is so far is... meh generic jrpg/rpg story line. However, it was the innovation with game mechanics for a jrpg that I was enjoying. Like a MMO it has a threat system. Balancing that threat bar to have your healer/squishies not be attacks and have your big swoll guy take all the damage. As well as mana regen in combat through either regular attack or when character turn ends (haven't figured out which one it was). As I keep playing though I do hope there are some more rpg elements like a class system or story choices... so on ward.. to keep playing and find out.    So far I would recommend it. For either a intro into the jrpg genre or just  innovation with the combat system. (This is atleast the first jrpg with these mechanics I've ran into... so their very well could be others that I've missed that have done the same thing.)

reviewText:
Skyborn is a fun RPG, and deceptively simple!
I tried to go into a in-depth review of it, but it turned out way too long, so I'll just go into a Pros and Cons type of points, with the full analysis for myself. If you're interested in it, I'll send you the whole review, just!

Pros
-Great world! It starts out fairly average, but it later reveals itself. It has a few interesting concepts, worth looking into.
-Unique combat system. It's a mixture of the classic turn-based combat, with a few more modern Skills and Gameplay concepts, akin to MMOs, like a threat system, big focus on buffs and debuffs rather than pure firepower, and good interaction and role separation between classes.
-It looks pretty good.
-Music is simply fantastic! It really reminded my of Golden Sun. While it's not quite at that level, it's still very good, and it feels more modern sounding. I really liked it.
-Provides a good challenge on Hard Mode without feeling too frustrating (until the last 2 Bosses, which are impossible unless you do absolutely every objective before heading into the final section of the game. However, nothing previously indicates that to be the case, which one is likely to miss, not realizing it until it's too late to go back.)
-No random encounters! You can see those encounters on the screen, approaching at will.
-Retry feature to get right back into a battle when you're defeated.
-Good control scheme (I personally used a controller for a more laid back experience, and it worked fine).

Cons
-Lack of any resolution options, leaving you with a very badly scaled game in Fullscreen, or just a small window (the latter is recommended, Fullscreen looke hideous).
-Poor interface design, looking very average, and not very functional.
-The crafting system was awful to navigate, and didn't provide much benefit, as you could earn enough gold to render it useless, as everything would be for sale.
-The game loved to surprise you with Boss Fights, and having you walk for half an hour if you did something wrong regarding leveling, or equipment. Some Boss Fights also appeared out of nowhere, sometimes making it impossible to procceed without reverting a couple of Saves.
-Low amount of Save Slots (only 4).
-The last few maps seemed a bit too clustered and confusing.
-Lack of information. This game is not very informative regarding some of its details, leaving it all to trial and error. Sometimes, it can be very damaging to the player's experience. Every shop, forge (for crafting) is very far apart, leaving the player with empty hands for long periods of time.
In the end, it was my downfall, as I literally couldn't go back, but HAD to, to be able to finish the game. Again, it does NOT give the player enough information for the player to make some decisions safely, but it was a big sore spot for me.


Overall, Skyborn was an enjoyable experience. I liked a lot of it! But, looking back at it, it is also riddled with so, so many issues...!
Some of those are inherent to RPGMaker, but some of those were also huge design flaws, which is disappointing.
If you're looking for a JRPG with a more modern feel, give this one a try! I enjoyed most of it.
Not recommended at full price, though, 15$ seems way too high for this game. It feels small at times,and just doesn't seem worth that price point, with so many amazing games at 10$.

reviewText:
Skyborn really impressed me. It cracked my top favorite RPG Maker games, some of which are, for example, LISA and Data Hacker. Firstly, something that always annoys me while playing these types of games is the utilization of the default resources available on the engine. Lots of games feature this negative aspect and that simply takes me off the title's experience. Skyborn basically has custom everything, from the tiles, to character design, to even battle effects and battle sounds. The soundtrack is also pretty amazing and I found it perfectly fitting the game's setting.

The story in Skyborn is a huge positive aspect in my books. A civil war is occuring in the realms where this title takes place. Skyborn wish to destroy and enslave Humanity, claiming they are a better species and were born for the purpose of ruling everything and everyone. Skyborn have wings. That's enough to convince you on what side you should take, am I right?

Four mechanics, and various little changes, distinguish this title from other RPG Maker games. The first being mining. By clicking on an ore located on a wall, you mine it. That simple. Secondly, crafting. Ores found by mining can be used in means of crafting new armor and weapons for your party. In third place comes augments. Items can be found all over various environments, which have the purpose of enhancing character's weapons/armor stats. And, lastly, side quest are available to extend a bit of the playtime this game can offer. I found 3 in total.

Concluding this review, my final thoughts are simple: if you've been looking for an RPG that provides some kind of nostalgia, and also made in RPG Maker, Skyborn is definitely worth your time and your money. It will not be easily forgettable, as the story is indeed well crafted, from the beggining to the very end. Recommended!

reviewText:
This is an RPG Maker game, which suffers many problems due to the use of that engine. Most notably is widescreen is not supported which in 2014, the release of this game, is kind of a glaring flaw. Along with that, the graphics are at an SNES level which is all the engine supports.

Graphics don't make a game though. So what about everything else?

Combat is turn-based which is ideal for me as that's my favorite type of RPG. Unfortunatly the balance of the abilities is fairly poor, and their variety lacking.

There is a small amount of customization avalible, and a rudamentary crafting system.

The story is so-so with around a high school writing level.

Overall the game is fairly mediocre. My recommendation is to pass, but if the description sparked your interest you should definatly wait for a sale, the game is not very long and offers zero replay.

reviewText:
Games designed with RPG Maker often get a lot of hate, due to the overall simplicity of the (basic) engine and the rate of sheer garbage that gets pushed out by wannabe game developers who have absolutely no idea what they're doing. But not all RPG Maker games are bad - just look at Skyborn.

It's certainly not perfect. It's a little rough around the edges, there's a few minor mapping errors here and there, there's a couple glitches, and the game balancing isn't the best... but it's okay. The overall mapping is beautiful and well designed, as are the graphics themselves which are largely custom made, featuring only a few of the basic RTP assets that come with RPG Maker. The music is all custom as far as I know, and is actually rather good. My only complaint is that none of the music loops for some reason, it just fades out and starts over.

Gameplay-wise, it's pretty solid, if unbalanced. It uses a variant of the Charge Turn Battle System (the one from Final Fantasy X), which is in my opinion one of the best battle systems available for RPG Maker. All of your party members are decided by plot progression, and you have very little control over what skills and spells they learn (only decided by two class change events partway through the game, which change which skills you will learn), but you rarely feel like you're lacking in skill variety, and most of your skills are actually useful in one way or another. You've got an offensive fighter, a tank, a healer, an offensive debuffer and a sort of battle-mage, and each party member fills their purpose pretty well, except for maybe Sullivan, the tank, who does a great tanking job, but lacks any real offensive options at all.

The main twist of the battle system is the Threat system, which brings MMO-style aggro into a turn-based RPG, where your party member's actions will determine how likely they will be to be attacked. But other than that, it's a pretty standard system, with a very heavy focus on managing buffs, debuffs and threat.

Story-wise, it's a pretty standard rebels-against-the-empire story, with a few little twists and turns. If you like the Steampunk setting, you'll like Skyborn, since it's all about steam engines and airships and stuff like that.

All in all, I'd recommend Skyborn. It's a pretty good JRPG-styled game on a platform with very few good games of the genre. It took me about 12 hours to beat the game, and I did pretty much everything there was to do (to my knowledge), so it's not a huge time investment, but it's fun while it lasts.

Skyborn. I thought maybe this was about dragons. I had no idea this is about dragoons. So as the story goes. YOu start out as a tinkerer named claret. So you can not name any of the characters for your own. so this is not a options game. I believe this is a RPG Maker VX ace game that was enhanced with mouse support and some keyboard support. I know a script on getting the keys E, S, F, D to work on this. Oh lol im talking about scripts. Well you arrive in a town that has no map. So good luck. not that i dont like games with no maps but its very confusing. However on this title I was not so lost as I have a high IQ to figure out where I have been and where I wanted to go. I did like the mouse support as this made the way of walking very easy to point and click to use.

Now hmm the game feels like your going to do some grinding but there is very little as if you look for the little experience points in the game, then you dont really grind at all. Now I was concerned about what that has to do with the support jobs to earn. I think that the way you use the different weapons are great but the way you can only get a certain number of upgrades from the character. So if your looking for a way to get better upgrades. I believe there should be a picture of what your trying to achieve. It is like blind crafting and what are we crafting and is it better. I know this is a different perspective but crafting blindly to achieve a greater craft? You will just have to play to see what I mean.

Five player support. Now that was a Party no doubt and the overall support of the last character was a 1:4 ratio as you are advancing with this character as to be like her. There are twist to her role and I support the team that came up with that. I wish there was more story to the Fey characters. If there is Skyborn 2 hopefully. I would try to support the character that is odd in the game and at least get a supply of weapons for her. I just feel characters need to support characters to a 50/50 percentage. That is how I feel I know that is not likely but character support would be nice. I do see that some of the characters really hate each other lol and so that was entertaining.

Okay so I beat it once but I would replay this as to try to work on the areas I failed to see. There is a point of no return in the game and you better pay attention. The boss at the end is extremely difficult and will let you know if your worthy. So you get a free battle it seems till he decides at 30% he's had enough of you and WHAM whole party is retrying. OH the Army of the military Skyborn seems incomplete as I was not sure who the commander was or was that the point.

Now the action of the sequence was intense. I did like the next character reference like something of Dragonwarrior series. I like to read the action. Can you tell? So you need 3 characters at all times. If you have 1 or 2 in the other areas of the game. I believe you will see a cruel fate mostly.

So with that said. I would recommend SKyborn to a player it is rare and seems like another of its kind shall embark soon....

reviewText:
Not bad, not great. Typical GBA style RPG if I had to throw it in a category. Kindof reminds me of Golden Sun or a FFIVish clone.

I really do enjoy the steampunk styling, the optional battles, the battles themselves, full mouse function (one handed skill ++), augmentation of items, and the threat system. The card-like battles are a nice break from the all-too-common sprite battles (insert FF memories here). The threat system is overwhelmingly my favorite part of this game; all monsters focus their attacks on the character with the highest threat. Threat is dependent on damage dealt (think enmity/paladin if you've played FFXI), and pretty much eliminates the whole sh*t-my-healer-died headache.

It's casual; you play it when you're watching investigative murder porn or whatever. I don't even know what the game music sounds like; I've played through it with iTunes on in the bkg, nothing's missed.

What I dislike:
i. the menus are quite primitive. I had difficulty quickly comparing armor pieces upon pickup.
ii. sprites for the monsters are overused. Haven't finished the game yet, but would've been interesting to see different models for different baddies.

Why should you consider it? It's 15$. That's a movie; play it for 2 hours and you've been more cost efficient with your wallet than going to see a lame Thor sequel. If you miss older rpg games before the community was obsessed with graphics, you'll probably like this psuedo-throwback.

Only played roughly 4hrs, but I've enjoyed every minute of it. My only complaint is some things are not described very well and some of the scenery could have taken a bit longer to touch up.

Edit: I was never much of a fan of old school JRPG's, but this one has me hooked and I probably will look at these more in the future. I like the scripting in the game most of all and is very rewarding if you take the time to explore. I LOVE exploring in games and this one has me doing a lot of it and it pays off everytime.
I strongly recommend this game to fans of this genre.
Please, for the love of everything holy, don't pay attention to people complaining that it was done with RPG Maker.... they all seem to have very biased opions

reviewText:
After going through the game twice I decided I'd review it. Let's start with the good:

Pros:
Probably the best overall of the RPG Maker games.
The protagonists are generally likeable and believable characters.
The antagonists do a good job of making you hate and want to beat them.
The game mechanics have a reasonable amount of depth and options that are introduced gradually throughout the course of the game which prevents information overload.
With one exception, the game plays fair and enemies generally have access to the same options and resources as the player.

Cons:
Very short, especially for an RPG.
Very easy, even on Hard difficulty. Even the optional superboss.
The final boss has an unavoidable death combo and the fight lasts long enough he usually gets at least one chance to use it on you at which point everyone dies. He is otherwise entirely trivial.
Mostly linear. There aren't many side quests overall and most of them are along the lines of complete an additional objective in the area you were going anyways instead of directing you somewhere else. It's also rare there is more than one place you could go and get something done at any given time.
Once you get past the first few levels you no longer gain skills by leveling up, only by reaching certain points in the game.

What I'd like to have seen:

At least twice as long.
Buff the difficulty considerably (leave Easy easy for those not looking for a hard game).
Buff all the final boss' attacks except for the unavoidable death combo, then either make sure you always have time to react or make it not always kill everyone instantly. That way he provides a hard but legitimate challenge.
More side quests and side areas.
Instead of class changing instantly granting all the skills, make it give one now and the rest with level requirements.
Massively buff the super boss. She's honestly a joke, her best attack does 2k or 3k on all at full power. Anyone complaining she's hard didn't go in prepared at all and is taking much more damage than that.

reviewText:
Difficulty leave: normal
playing casually not really puting forced thought and not really Saving and undoing mistakes just playing as if it were a fun game.

Pros:
The art is beaufitful it's really great and it seems to be rather clean then pixels.

The Mechanics/ ui
Everything runs smoothly, their interfaces for each menu look pretty and are very informative. I like the touches they did with the battles. Overal the Ui is being the Ui and doing it's job. telling me what I need to know without overwhelming me with boxes upon boxes.

Story
The story really interest me. has a bit of clice [parents left turns out they were rebels blah] but it's all clice when you look at all rpgs. The storys great you really can see how they play out in some scenes

weapon crafting
Unique and some what nice.

status effects
Players arn't restricted in status effects. all effects only lessen things and nothing takes away a players turn. blind something that would make you miss lowers your damage. there hasn't been a sleep spell nor has there been something that disables my player and makes me feel like that person is useless until there status effect is removed. any time I attack I feel that I'm doing something.

Cons:

Give a character a double attack.
I craft a steel weapon [probably teir 2-3] and recieve a weapon in a dungeon i'm dealing 400 per hit twice. and if charged for a moment 1k possibly. This really hurts the fact that the main chracter is dealing all the damage. I get that 1's a healer 1's a tank and then you have your character. but for the early story thats 1 person dealing tons of damage 2-3 shotting all the monsters for no reason.... no reason at all. My tank tanks and my healers heals are kind of weak. and my 4th party memeber who is crit happy only deals 150 base damage. so I have to protect the double attacker because she is all my damage... :/ makes the game feel like I'm forced to deal all damage with her.

Weapon crafting limitation
So I can't see what weapons I'm making or what armor I'm making and I understand something basic like a mage can't wear something heavy. and my tank shouldn't wear light things. but what does it all make? not knowing what desicion I'm making really hurts when I build a +2 damage for my damage dealer and get a new weapon in that dungeon moments later. or when I build something for my tank to attack and deal more damage to gain threat for the finishing blow and he gets a weapon. You can't craft weapons for other party memebers that I know of just yet. the first 4 you get you make weapons for the people who get items in the dungeon.... it makes crafting weapons worthless early on. and How was I to know?  I've just wasted resorces thats what I know.

difficulty/ bosses
bosses on normal difficulty arn't fun... You fight monsters 2-3 shot each of them, sometimes 1 shot. you fight the boss [which i've encountered 3] they hit all of your party memebers they 3 shot the tank and the 6 shot the person i'm desperatly keeping alive using heal all the potions I can throw on her because shes the ONLY ONE that can HURT THE BOSS. and a tech boss [2nd boss] and a female skyborn boss [3rd boss] share the ablity that gives them haste + all stats pretty much. :/ like really...

Money issues. what exactly has real value...

Your shops seem rather strange. you don't buy weapons you buy augments which can only be put on 1 weapon. ontop of that you don't need potions because you 2-3 shot everything. and you have a healer that uses 2-1% of mana to cast heal. and the mana used has no issues. no one has mana problems. :/ your tank uses 0 mana to taunt. your damage uses 22% to deal aoe damage which sets ablaze sometimes. and your crit happy person uses it to blind people. which just lowers damage and doesn't affect bosses... I have no clue what to spend the money on since Augments really seem like a 1 item use and you don't feel a value for them.

Early game healer/ healing outside of comabt,

healer in dungeon 1. It is little to no cost to heal and it has the problems of not really doing much of a heal inside of battle. The regen ablity is nice. and dehablity is nice but your taking a party memeber giving them the healler roll. so giving them damage doesn't really help your team. if your a healer. you need to use your action to heal. not deal damage.

No grind factor.

all encounters are plotted. meaning I can't go off and grind if i'm struggling with a boss. It's fine if the enemies are plotted but if they are. they need a respawn or their needs to be a way I can grind if I feel I'm unable to progress. If i'm struggling it means I've made a mistake with my resources but I have no way of destroying my weapon to craft armor. or to craft anything that could really help me out. heck I don't even know what teir my armor is when I get it because when I crafted new armor it was same teir as class 1 and I had no clue. their for MORE resorces wasted.



Final analysis


I played the game and I'll still play the game for more research if my mind changes on this game and i'll rereview it but from first dungeons and bosses if it remains the same then It's going to stay this way.

Art 5/5
Game play 2/5
Sound 4/5
price 2/5
Story 4/5

FInal verdict 6/10

Buy it if it's on sale for under 10 maybe 8 dollars but its not worth your 15 dollars... it really isn't Their are plenty of games that look nice sound nice but play better then what this has to offer in its early on game play.

reviewText:
If you're an RPG fan I'd say pick this game up while it's on sale (at least 75% off) or in a bundle. I found the story premise to be interesting, the art to be overall nice looking, and the dungeons to be well designed. It's a fun game worth playing, but the asking price is entirely too high for what the game is.

The following reasons are why I think that the game isn't worth what they are asking for it:
1) The game is WAY too short for the pricetag. I did absolutely everything to do in game--all the sidequests as well as the optional bosses--and I clocked in at just under 15 hours of in-game time, which includes a few times when I left the game open while doing other things. I would expect at least 15 hours of base gameplay and 3~5 hours of extras for what amounts to about $15 USD.

2) The plot was interesting, but extremely under developed; the ending also did not wrap things up as well as it could have. I would have liked to see a lot more time spent developing the world lore--both historical and present--in side quests and other optional events. I would also have liked to see more intra-character development in optional quests, events, and other places.

3) The crafting system, while a good idea, was poorly designed. The UI was terrible (generic message window instead of a more in-depth interface that would let you know exactly what you were crafting) and the only things worth crafting were the +2 weapons. If this system had given the TLC it deserved, it could have added hours on to the fun bonus content.

4)  The battle system is poorly balanced. I went through the entire game in hard mode. On the plus side, the beginning part of the game was actually hard enough so that I had to use items (I am a person who stockpiles items for when I need them" and then never uses them)

reviewText:
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an action role-playing video game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. It is the fifth installment in The Elder Scrolls action role-playing video game series, following The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. Skyrim was released on November 11, 2011, for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. Three downloadable content (DLC) add-ons were released—Dawnguard, Hearthfire, and Dragonborn—which were repackaged into The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Legendary Edition, which released on June 4, 2013.

Skyrim's main story revolves around the player character's efforts to defeat Alduin the World-Eater, a dragon who is prophesied to destroy the world. Set two hundred years after the events of Oblivion, the game takes place in the fictional province of Skyrim. Over the course of the game, the player completes quests and develops their character by improving their skills. Unlike previous The Elder Scrolls games, Skyrim does not require the player to select a character class at the beginning of the game, negating a problem the development team felt previous entries had by forcing the player into a rigid play-style too early into the game. Skyrim continues the open world tradition of its predecessors by allowing the player to travel anywhere in the game world at any time, and to ignore or postpone the main storyline indefinitely.

The game was developed using the in-house Creation Engine, built specifically for the game. Skyrim is not a direct sequel to previous The Elder Scrolls games, and was considered a spiritual successor to Oblivion and 2008's Fallout 3. The team opted for a more unique and diverse game world than Oblivion's Cyrodiil, which game director and executive producer Todd Howard considered less interesting by comparison. The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim was released to critical acclaim, with reviewers particularly responding well to the refined character development and setting. The game shipped over seven million copies to retailers within the first week of its release, and sold over 20 million copies across all three platforms.

Gameplay
See also: Gameplay of The Elder Scrolls series

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an action role-playing game, playable from either a first- or third-person perspective. The player may freely roam over the land of Skyrim, which is an open world environment consisting of wilderness expanses, dungeons, cities, towns and villages.[3] The player may navigate the game world more quickly by riding horses, or by utilizing a fast-travel system that allows them to warp to previously-discovered locations.[4] The game's main quest can be completed or ignored at the player's preference after the first stage of the quest is finished. Non-player characters (NPCs) populate the world and can be interacted with in a number of ways; the player may engage them in conversation, marry an eligible NPC or kill them. As in previous Elder Scrolls games, killing certain NPCs can make some quests or items unobtainable. Some NPCs cannot be killed. If witnessed, crimes like murder and theft accrue the player bounty points in each of the world's nine districts. Should the player be stopped by a guard, they may wipe their bounty with gold or jail time, or may resist arrest which will trigger an aggressive pursuit. NPCs may allocate the player additional side-quests, and some side-quests have parameters adjusted based on nearby dungeons the player has yet to explore.[5][6] Some NPCs that are befriended or hired by the player may act as companions who will accompany the player and provide aid in combat.[7] The player may choose to join factions, which are organized groups of NPCs such as the Dark Brotherhood, a band of assassins or the player may choose to destroy them.[8] Each of the factions has an associated quest path to progress through. The cities and towns in the game world each have an economy, which the player can stimulate by completing jobs such as farming.[9]
The player character engages in combat with monsters while exploring a dungeon. The player may dual-wield weapons and magic at once in order to be more effective against enemies.

A perpetual objective for the player is to develop their character. At the beginning of the game, the player creates their character by selecting one of several races, including humans, elves and anthropomorphic (including cat and lizard-like) creatures, and then customizes their character's appearance.[10] Over the course of the game, the player improves their character's skills, which are numerical representations of their ability in certain areas. There are eighteen skills divided evenly between the three schools of combat, magic and stealth. When the player has trained skills enough to meet the required experience, their character levels up. Each time their character levels, the player may choose to select a skill-specific ability called a perk, or store perk points for later use. Unlike earlier entries in The Elder Scrolls series which used a character class system to determine which skills would contribute to the character's leveling, Skyrim allows the player to discover preferred skills as they play the game and rewards the player with more experience when a frequently-used skill is leveled.[5][11] A head-up display (HUD) appears when any of the player's three main attributes are being depleted. Attributes regenerate over time, although this process can be accelerated by using potions or regenerative spells. Health is depleted primarily when the player takes damage, and the loss of all health results in death. Magicka is depleted by the use of spells and by being struck by lightning-based attacks. Stamina determines the player's effectiveness in combat and is depleted by sprinting, power attacking, and being struck by frost-based attacks. The player's inventory can be accessed from the menu and items can be viewed in 3D, which may prove essential in solving puzzles found in dungeons.[12]

reviewText: Without a doubt, one of the more enjoyable jrpg's, there's enough story driving you through each area for it to not feel nearly as repetitive as most of them. Even the music will make you raise an eyebrow in notice every now and then, the game feels like the devs actually cared about it. Downsides, it IS a rather short game, took about 5+ hrs to complete, but that's because you never actually have to grind. Also, although it is story driven, there are few extra areas to explore, gameplay is very linear. Despite this, still felt like a very enjoyable and complete package, pick it up if you want a good story to hold you through a day.

reviewText: It seems to me that this game was primarily made by an artist: The art is beautiful, but the programming / systems involved are not particularly complex. Fortunately, there was a lot of hard work put into them, and despite being a simplistic affair, the combat is balanced and even strategically challenging on harder difficulties. One particular (optional) fight, which I later discovered defaulted to the hard difficulty, was amoung the most challenging RPG fights I have ever done, and yet, it was not arbitrary... it just required a lot of strategy... though by the time I finished it, I was pretty much untouchable.\n\nIn the meantime, if you don't care too much about the battles, you can drop the difficulty to easy and enjoy roughly ten hours of a well told story. It's not quite Bioshock, but many a sucessful AAA title has gone to field with worse, and it's engaging enough that I played through it in one go, without feeling any desire to stop midway through. Nor did I feel the need for a walkthrough or to look up advice on the game, which was fortunate, since there is rather little.

reviewText:
This game looked great when I started to play it. The graphics were nice, and the steampunk theme went along really well.
But there was just one part that ruined my experience.
The controls.
I just couldn't play this.
I couldn't edit the controls in the options menu, and I had to click on my mouse instead of using the arrow keys or WASD.
Whenever I clicked, the character I was controlling would go all over the place, instead of where I need the character to go.
Like when I click to the left, the character would go left, make a turn, go right, then go down.
This keeps on happening and I just decided to stop playing.
DON'T BUY THIS GAME!!!

reviewText: Played about an hour into it, it's a very well-made RPG game and the character art is GORGEOUS. reviewText:
Tl;DR: Bugs, awful storyline that could've been written by a twelve year old, same old pixel-rpg elements, brings nothing worthwhile to the table. 3/10

For the however-long I played this game, I never want to play it again. I was lucky enough to get it free in a giveaway, but if you are considering paying for this, I beg you to consider your money put elsewhere.

The story, and characters, are quite frankly, abyssmal. You play Claret Spencer, your typical 18 (16? I don't know she was never given an age.) year old-raging-on-hormones-because-all-girls-do-that shop mechanic. The characters act so suprised about things that should be understood so easily. The characters had to re-explain to Claret over and over certain aspects of the universe, like skyborns and magic. I've been here for ten minutes and I understand everything in this games history better than the main character that has spent her life here.

As for bugs, straight off the first weird conversation scene thing, you walk out of your shop and can just ♥♥♥♥ing walk through guard rails and stairs to stand in puddles or walls. The stairs are also really gimicky, sometimes you get thrown off of them into walls and stuff, but don't worry, just phase your way back into reality by walking in said wall till you reach the actual path again.

This game brings nothing new that is worthwhile to the table. It has a threat" system
date: where enemies attack whoever of your party attacks them more
recommended: which at first seems like a cool idea
hoursPlayed: till you get a mage and relize you can constantly heal the character they're attacking and never worry about said mage taking damage
helpfulPercent: making combat boring pretty fast.\n\nWARNING: SPOILERS -- What I really wanted from this game was choice
votesHelpful: I wanted to join the super-cool skyborn soldiers but instead the game makes them out to be complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who try to kill you

votesFunny: whenever they meet you. At one point you're told to follow the rebels back to their hideout and report back to a skyborn to get your brother out of prison. I was totally ready to do that
commentsCount: but then the "Red Spectre" tells you what "horrible" people the skyborn are
column16: torturing humans to see if they can use magic. I didn't care

reviewText:
Usually I don't write reviews on steam and I'm not even very far into the game yet, but Skyborn has surprised me with it's quality so far and that's why I'll write down my early impression of it now.

Okay, since I don't know much about the story yet, I'll just say that I enjoyed the events that happened around the main characters to start up the adventure so far. That's probably because the characters are really charmingly written and there weren't any cheesy lines that made me cringe like in most of the homemade RPG-Maker games. Even the character that I thought I would hate at the beginning, turned out to be very likeable and sort of funny very fast =)

Next would be the music, which is in my humble opinion very solid orchestral music that always fits the environment. The dungeon music is mysterious and calm, the battle music is kind of epic, majestic and uplifting and overall the music is just very nice to listen to. Stylewise the tracks feel always very gentle, atmospheric, diversified and not just right up in your face, which I like a lot.

Now to the battlesystem. Optically it has a typical RPG-Maker interface, without dynamicly fighting charactermodels, but that's fine for me, because all and all the drawn character models and the interface are very pretty.
The battles are turnbased and revolve around the classic HP / MP formular with the little change that is the Threat-Bar. Everytime your characters attack the enemies the Threat-Bar of those characters fill up depending on how much damage they deal and the character with the highest Threat get's attacked by the enemies, except of course when the enemies use multi-target attacks. So since you get a tank-like character very early on you want to use him exactly like that and let the others do damage/healing/status effects while keeping up the Threat-Level on the tank. Also i would recommend anyone to play this game on Hard, because that is when the battles actually get fun and strategic. So, uh... I like it =D

Last but not least, the graphics are very well meshed together and the mapping is always very detailed, pretty, and never feels unnatural. Also, getting around in the dungeons never felt tedious so far, since the maps feel very natural to get through and the monsters are optional obstacles to fight (don't know if that changes later).
Also I dig the Steampunk-Style =)

To round this review up:
It's a very fun classical RPG with charming characters, good dialogue, a (so far) promising story, a slightly changed turnbased battle-system, very nice music, nice mapping, good pacing and a nice steampunk environment.

I like it !!! =)
I've been enjoying this jrpg style RPGMaker game.\nGood job!

The game was good, it had a great storyline (in my opinion) and it reminded me of my love for RPGs, it's clearly made with the rpg maker VXAce, and I was disappointed to see the lack of spelling errors, (there were maybe 2 or 3). Truthfully, it isn't worth the full price of $14.99, but it was worth every penny I spent on it. (I got it with the rpg maker humble bundle, it was worth about 10 cents for me). The game is really short, I beat it in about 4 hours, but there are plenty of side quests for you to do if you're easily distracted. I'll probably give it an 8 out of 10.

Amazing little RPG. Wonderful characters and writing, beautiful artwork, good mechanics. I beat the game and all the sidequests aside from one optional boss in about 18 hours so it's a reasonable length. Some people might not like the $15 price tag for an 18 hour RPG Maker game but definately pick it up on sale.
The most awesome RPG game i've ever played! Fun, beautifull graphics and an awesome storyline.
If you like classic RPGs, you play Skyborn ! It's great game ! Interesting story, great characters, nice soundtracks and cool combat system ! 10/10 :-)

This is an awesome game! I generally have two requirements for a game: Good story, and visually pleasing. This is both. And on top of that, it has great music!

I breezed through it in about 8 hours, but I'm also severely directionally challenged and tend to wander around the same areas several times, just in case I missed something. This is a good game for wandering, especially in some of the later levels because it's just darn pretty! If you're like me and you want to do ALL THE QUESTS and find ALL THE THINGS, you can probably get another few hours out of it.

Aditionally, when they tell you that you're about to go past the point of no return, they really mean it! If you have unfinished quests, or if you just want to meander through some areas again, make sure you do it before taking on that mission.

Overall, it's a gorgeous game, great music, and a wonderful story line. Definitely worth the money.
Great cast, fun playment, and a storyline that is both fun and at times almost depressing.

Skyborn is a simple 2D game made in rpg maker. the combat is mediocre but lets face it your not playing an rpg maker game for the combat. Skyborn lists an array of interesting characters and a story line that will make you want to keep playing to see how it unfolds. I would recommend it as the price range meets up with what you would expect from a simple little game.

Skyborn is a game that I initially expected to dislike, the early dialogue is really blunt exposition that occasionally resembles a flashback episode. The game continues to push you through scripted pieces about an evil race of winged people with early twists that move so fast I hardly remember them. If you've played these kind of games on super NES this is comfort food almost that's too comfortable as the harder fights are in a Colosseum, as very few fights in the main quest will challenge those who put ingots into their weapons.

Yet the game eventually won me over and cleansed my snickering black heart, the game's humor is gentle and devoid of overt references and while the writing remains blunt the complete lack of cynicism lowered my defenses and was even invested in what will happen to the girl from the sewers. There is such care into keeping your attention and making the environments rewarding to explore, there are no random battles and numerous hidden places where exp boosts hide, creepy barflies that offer you suspicious drinks, and even a constantly hungry lady.

For seven hours I played this and upgraded my swords and rivet guns, a bit short for those who miss 40 hour games  from the 90s but a not a second too long. The game not only is aware of the past it embraces those old games wholeheartedly like the most affectionate love letter.

Ah nice little old school jrpg style game. Pretty linear but you can do a couple things on the side if you want or don't want for experience. If you are a fan of the old nes and snes jrpg you will probably like this. This is more snes or maybe a bit better in graphics to me. Just because it says it's an rpgmaker game does not mean it is bad.

Skyborn is a beautifully crafted world with art work that reminsces from the SNES era. The graphics and art are better than that, but the RPG style is exactly the same.

Anyone who played those games, I mean really played them love them. You'll love Skyborn too. It mostly does everything those games did.

However Skyborn is a small game. I would call this a one and done deal. You play it once, feel fully satisfied, and never touch it again. That's ok. Not every game has to be a game you play a bunch of times. Not every book is a book you read multiple times. Not every movie is a movie you watch more than once. Enjoy the game for what it is because it is a lot of fun. I had a great time with it.

Classic JRPG feel with better graphics. If that's what you're looking for, you'll get it in this pint sized adventure. If you spend 4 hours on this game, you rushed through it and shame on you. If you spend 6 or more, you spent time and explored.
A fun, fairly short RPG.
Enjoyed the game to the fullest, considering I rarely play these types of games, did not once regret this purchase.

Usually I don't write reviews on steam and I'm not even very far into the game yet, but Skyborn has surprised me with it's quality so far and that's why I'll write down my early impression of it now.

Okay, since I don't know much about the story yet, I'll just say that I enjoyed the events that happened around the main characters to start up the adventure so far. That's probably because the characters are really charmingly written and there weren't any cheesy lines that made me cringe like in most of the homemade RPG-Maker games. Even the character that I thought I would hate at the beginning, turned out to be very likeable and sort of funny very fast =)

Next would be the music, which is in my humble opinion very solid orchestral music that always fits the environment. The dungeon music is mysterious and calm, the battle music is kind of epic, majestic and uplifting and overall the music is just very nice to listen to. Stylewise the tracks feel always very gentle, atmospheric, diversified and not just right up in your face, which I like a lot.

Now to the battlesystem. Optically it has a typical RPG-Maker interface, without dynamicly fighting charactermodels, but that's fine for me, because all and all the drawn character models and the interface are very pretty.
The battles are turnbased and revolve around the classic HP / MP formular with the little change that is the Threat-Bar. Everytime your characters attack the enemies the Threat-Bar of those characters fill up depending on how much damage they deal and the character with the highest Threat get's attacked by the enemies, except of course when the enemies use multi-target attacks. So since you get a tank-like character very early on you want to use him exactly like that and let the others do damage/healing/status effects while keeping up the Threat-Level on the tank. Also i would recommend anyone to play this game on Hard, because that is when the battles actually get fun and strategic. So, uh... I like it =D

Last but not least, the graphics are very well meshed together and the mapping is always very detailed, pretty, and never feels unnatural. Also, getting around in the dungeons never felt tedious so far, since the maps feel very natural to get through and the monsters are optional obstacles to fight (don't know if that changes later).
Also I dig the Steampunk-Style =)

To round this review up:
It's a very fun classical RPG with charming characters, good dialogue, a (so far) promising story, a slightly changed turnbased battle-system, very nice music, nice mapping, good pacing and a nice steampunk environment.

I like it !!! =)
I've been enjoying this jrpg style RPGMaker game.\nGood job!

Skyborn is . . . competent, I guess I'd say. Not amazing, but not bad.

Its strongest points are the setting, story, and characters. Admittedly, there are a lot of bog standard tropes across the board, but they're pretty well-executed. The world is interesting, and I found myself wanting to know more about it. The characters are well-written and more fun than I expected. The story could have benefited from more development and better pacing, but still, it was engaging enough to keep me playing to the end (seven hours or so).

That's more than I can say for the combat, however. My biggest issue with the game is how boring the combat became. I'm not an RPG veteran by any stretch, and I paid almost no attention to Skyborn's mechanics, yet I was still able to snooze through all but one fight. Sooner rather than later, Claret got some mega-OP skills that obliterated anything that tried to get in her way, which completely trivialized most of the enemies and turned encounters into tedious detours. Also, the combat screen uses default RPG Maker enemy sprites, which often look weirdly out of place amongst the otherwise consistent anime aesthetics.

Final verdict: yes, it's worth playing, but wait for a sale.

I got this game with a humble bundle for RPGMaker and some addons. Not a bad game. Not bad at all. But not worth 15$ in the least. The story is very interesting and has an amazing premise and the battle system is pretty cool. There where some parts where I had to go back and level more in order to even stand a chance against some creatures, but I wroked through it like a normal RPG. Like the controls and Gameplay. But again, an 8-bot 16-bit game with only 5-8 hours of gameplay on hard difficulty, not worth the price.

For a pretty cheap game, the story and play style were very impressive. With more than 6 hours of game play, this game was definitely worth the price. A simplified version of final fantasy combat system, it is very easy to get used to the battles and the UI. One of my favorite stories that I have played in a long time, I would give this game a 9/10.

Short Version: This game is worth a buy and a playthrough or three.

Long Version: (Note, there will be spoilers below, so read at your own risk)

GRAPHICS: Beautiful, from the sprites to the art. The sprites themselves had excellent articulation (Claret's hammering and Dhacian's sword come to mind), and the various expressions of the characters were extremely well done. The Claret-in-Prometheus-Engine sprite seemed a teensy bit off (color-wise) in a couple of frames (and I was dissappointed that it didn't replace the standard walking sprite in the final dungeon), but not jarringly so. The artist really should get a round of applause.

WRITING: This game's writing is very well done. In terms of plot, the story is familiar without being boring, and unusual without needing a compendium's worth of beforehand knowledge. The dialogue is both written and presented well. I know you don't know me, but that is very high praise coming from me; I am unbelievably nitpicky when it comes to dialogue and dialogue presentation. Skyborn does both quite well. The characters are believable and well-written, and especially unusual is that I did not find even one single character annoying!

SOUND: Very good. The music always fit the mood of the scene and was never once annoying. The choice to not use the battle theme in tense moments keeps the player immersed in the feeling of the scene. I have no complaints about the music.

MECHANICS: Autodash is wonderful, as always. The battle system works well with all available features and functions. Sometimes I swear I just couldn't keep threat on Sullivan, but the threat system was rewarding and satisfying no less. Mechanically, the game is sound. I do have a few issues that I will outline below:

- The Platina Coin augment does not confer blind as is stated by its description, but silence instead.
- The status effects are not adequately described ingame; without having and using a skill that causes them, it's difficult to know what a status effect does when it's inflicted on you or an enemy.
- The overall effect of the +1-4 Metal Ingots could have been explained better. I had no idea that it affected more than just attack damage and weight.
- The Exploration Points (sp?) seemed oddly out of place. There was no counter keeping track of how many I'd found, and frankly, they seemed like a last minute addition to re-balance the game. They come off as a bit of a clumsy afterthought to me.

AESTHETICS: All in all, this game is pleasant to both look at and play. The maps are well made, being both intuitive and easy to figure out (and believe me, I've seen some downright OFFENSIVE mapping in some games). The art was fantastic (Saehral really outdid herself), the sound was great, and the dialogue was arranged well. In terms of battle animations, I'd have perhaps liked to see some more custom ones, rather than stock RPGMaker animations, but they still convey what is necessary. There were a few capitalization errors in a few item descriptions, in particular the Branch of Life, Ether, Medical Herb and Potion, but not everybody is a Grammar Nazi.

CONCLUSION: This is more than an above-average game; this is a very good game that's easily worth the full price. It'll keep you busy for 10 hours minimum - more if you take care of all the bonus content - and you'll have a good time while you're at it.

Skyborn does a lot of things right and a lot of things wrong. In general I can tentatively recommend buying this game. Best to wait for a sale.
Having said that here is a rundown of things that the game does right, only to squander it.

-The game introduces early on an airship. This is great and makes for a nice start. Only it goes nowhere with this, you can only use it very late in game to travel to old areas and not many at that. Considering the short length of the game, I wonder why it was included at all.

-Tileset and general look of the game is very nice, if you like the RPGmaker. It feels all very cohesive and fitting. Sadly there is very little interaction with the environment. No flavor text when looking through bookshelfs or things like that.

-No random battles is a nice change of pace. In general the combat is well thought out and nuanced. Such a shame then that the game can't be arsed to tell you that. Nearly all mechanics go unexplained, the different dmg sources and how they are dependent on your stats goes unmentioned and the buff mechanic is a huge mess.
The only indicator what buffs/debuffs your characters have are small shifting Icons, which I still haven't completely learned by the end of the game. Though that is still a lot better than what you know about the enemy. You can't check whether your debuff is still active on him, only see once it's applied and it pops out briefly once it fades. If you haven't paid attention for a single turn, you might have missed that your debuffs are gone. Which can mean instant death against the tough optional bosses.

So why recommend it? The story is nice and manages to tell a tale driven by it's characters. Those same characters manage to feel real enough, though I guess that is a matter of taste. So again, a tentative recommendation.
If you like RPG's with a good story and you like steampunk style games. This is a definite buy!
very nice story, and the combat is fast and fun.
Don't be discouraged to get this because it's made on RPGMaker! It's a great (albeit short) game with awesome music tracks. Perfect for those that do not like random encounters and do not like grind!

An endlessly charming and simple Japanese-style RPG that brings to mind Square's SNES efforts, as well as lesser-known Genesis and Turbografx adventures (Lunar and Cosmic Fantasy come immediately to mind).  Easy to grasp mechanics and an interesting story punctuated with excellent writing and the first truly likeable cast I've come across in quite some time.  It speaks volumes that I enjoyed this humble little title more than recent multi-million efforts from big name developers.  It's quite succinct at only 7-10 hours long, but there's also little pointless backtracking and padding to slog through.

Absolutely recommended to gamers that look back fondly on the golden age of console RPGs.

Note: Disregard people dismissing Skyborn because of the engine it was built with.  RPG Maker is fully capable of producing unique and captivating games in the right hands, as evidenced by Yume Nikki, To the Moon and the subject of this review.

Surprinsingly enjoyable. I did not think that I would like an rpgmaker game as much as this one, especially since it's turn-based. I got the game when it was free, so wait for a sale.

Awesome points:
There is a lot of freedom in this game. You can do whatever you want, whenever you want. There's crafting, an arena, collectables and tons of places to explore.
The story is pretty well written. The characters were memorable. Their individual storylines were awesome to read and wove into the main story really well. (Personally, Alda's is my favourite storyline. Especially the end.)
It plays a little like a visual novel. With fighting and exploring. Not bad. Lots of reading.
Downsides include:
Lack of map, extremely easy to get lost. I would love to have a minimap or something to show locations.
Very little tooltips. Though, that may be an upside as well? It takes a bit of experimenting and trial & error to work out exactly what's going on in the game.
Mouse interaction was not smooth. It was difficult to navigate the inventory. Mouse control over the menus was pretty clunky as well.
Quest menu sucked. Sometimes the writing at the end would be cut off and it was impossible to read the last couple of steps. Sometimes I forgot who I had to return my sidequest to, as the place wasn't stated. Ended up running around for half an hour talking to everyone I came across.
If you can deal with the downsides, the game is enjoyable and worth the time.
Fun for a while, then the balancing issues kick in. Then it just gets ridiculous.

Short version:
I finished my first playthrough of the game in 7 hours on easy mode. I enjoyed it and recommend this game.

Story: 8/10
Visual: 7/10
Audio: 9/10
>>>Overall: 8/10

Long version:
This game has many unique plot interests and story points that truly feel planned and thought out rather than the scripted tropes many RPG Maker games force on players. Also, there is some room at the end for a possible sequel. The locations to explore, though somewhat easy to lose one's self in, remind me of old school RPGs that did not hold your hand with a map or perfectly linear routes (I honestly prefer this style, it makes you have to think or make notes). The music to this game was very fitting and truly gave me the full experience I'm sure the developers were intending. I appreciated how it flowed well with the art style and visual feel of the game. The one thing I wished to see was character pictures in chat for all talking NPCs that did not have character busts.. it's odd to me seeing a text box show up with no image. I also wish the game had cause to visit more locations, since the game could've easily extended to a total of 12 hours with how much backstory and develpment they could have entertained.

Overall, this has been one of the better RPG Maker derived games that I have played, and truly one that was worth the money. I hope you folks out there on Steam give this a chance, and I hope that you developers reading this are already working on a followup for this excellently crafted game. Thank you.

This is an awesome game! I generally have two requirements for a game: Good story, and visually pleasing. This is both. And on top of that, it has great music!

I breezed through it in about 8 hours, but I'm also severely directionally challenged and tend to wander around the same areas several times, just in case I missed something. This is a good game for wandering, especially in some of the later levels because it's just darn pretty! If you're like me and you want to do ALL THE QUESTS and find ALL THE THINGS, you can probably get another few hours out of it.

Aditionally, when they tell you that you're about to go past the point of no return, they really mean it! If you have unfinished quests, or if you just want to meander through some areas again, make sure you do it before taking on that mission.

Overall, it's a gorgeous game, great music, and a wonderful story line. Definitely worth the money.

Good story and a good pace throughout.

Visuals are good with some things being slightly off due to this being made on rpgmaker, the theme is fantastic but due to the retrictive tile based system you end up with all land being made of squares. The square angular beaches look so weird.


Battle system if very fun, with a threat mechanic similar to mmo's yet turn based.

Its really short though with the main quest taking me just under 9 hours.

Its still worth playing and I would actually suggest this to people who like mmo's due to the fun battle style.

First off, ignore all the complaining about RPG maker.  If an RPG has a good plot in an interesting setting with unique characters and a good combat system, who cares how it was made?  Luckily, Skyborn has all this and more.  It starts off fairly easy but the combat system has enough depth to really give you a challenge after the first few areas.  I played on medium difficulty and I found the battles challenging and fun.  There are also plenty of optional battles in the late game that will challenge you, but they're not needed to beat the game. The story is the best part of Skyborn.  There's a unique setting combined with memorable characters.  The game is a nice length as well.  It's probably 11 to 15 hours total.  I did all 4 sidequests along with the arena and the Venom Depths which are optional, along with maybe 45 minutes of afking for dinner, beer, and bathroom breaks.\n\nAs far as the details of the game go, I enjoyed the level design.  Graphics are SNES level, but I'm playing for the plot and there were some moments where certain levels looked quite pleasing and so I'd say the graphics are fine for the genre.  The plot and setting were great.  This isn't a generic steampunk cliché universe.  There's no annoying puzzles and all but one time it was clear where to go next. The crafting and augmenting system is deep enough to cause you to put some real thought into what to upgrade and it's fairly open.  You can skip crafting if you like, but it's fun to forge very powerful weapons for your favorite character.  The music was ok, not fantastic.  Sound effects were solid.  In the first 2 to 3 hours of the game, the enemies can seem a little repetitive and it's a bit too easy (on medium) but that changes.  There's also no real grinding" levels.  Enemies do not respawn so it's to your advantage to fight every enemy
date: but you don't just have to sit around leveling up.  Bosses are challenging and feel epic.  Overall
recommended: I'd give the game an 8/10 for being an enjoyable
hoursPlayed: well made RPG.  It's a bit expensive at the current 15$ price tag
voteText: but if you can pick up this game on a sale
helpfulPercent: it's worth it."
