reviewText: While it's no Final Fantasy of Yore, Skyborn is a solid game with an interesting battle gimmick and a fairly solid story. While it's not worth the price set in today's massive market, I'd say it's still worth getting- especially if you spot it on sale.

Skyborn had a fun cast of playable characters and a combat system that's simple yet enjoyable. It's sort of short but a pleasurable experience all around. If you want something that won't take a lot of time, I'd recommend this game.

I got Skyborn in a bundle a while back and played it last week, and it's a surprisingly decent game - there's almost no grinding, the characters are fairly diverse (though there's a slight flaw with one of them due to how his MP mechanic works in the late game), it's somewhat well written (though the plot is fairly generic) and it doesn't overstay it's welcome (since it's only 8hrs long, though I imagine you could get another one or two with the bonus dungeon I didn't touch). It may not be worth £12, but I could see it being worth buying at 66% or 75% off if you fancy a decent JRPG or RPGMaker game.
very nice story, and the combat is fast and fun.
Don't be discouraged to get this because it's made on RPGMaker! It's a great (albeit short) game with awesome music tracks. Perfect for those that do not like random encounters and do not like grind!

An endlessly charming and simple Japanese-style RPG that brings to mind Square's SNES efforts, as well as lesser-known Genesis and Turbografx adventures (Lunar and Cosmic Fantasy come immediately to mind).  Easy to grasp mechanics and an interesting story punctuated with excellent writing and the first truly likeable cast I've come across in quite some time.  It speaks volumes that I enjoyed this humble little title more than recent multi-million efforts from big name developers.  It's quite succinct at only 7-10 hours long, but there's also little pointless backtracking and padding to slog through.

Absolutely recommended to gamers that look back fondly on the golden age of console RPGs.

Note: Disregard people dismissing Skyborn because of the engine it was built with.  RPG Maker is fully capable of producing unique and captivating games in the right hands, as evidenced by Yume Nikki, To the Moon and the subject of this review.

Great classic RPG feel to the game with a decent storyline. The music is very nice, and there are skills and members to keep the fighting fun. It is also very rewarding to explore, which keep you interested. On the downside the game is a bit short, but still worth the time and money.

For a casual RPG player like myself, Skyborn was a wonderful little game with a poignant story, fun gameplay, and quick pace.  There was never a need for tedious grinding--in fact, you could avoid most battles if you wanted to, but I don't know how that would affect your leveling.  Shops were placed conveniently between stretches of dungeon to buy (or make) better weapons and armor.  You could also buy supplies, although the plentiful item chests usually provided enough for me.  Some areas (Nordenwald Forest *cough*) were rather lengthy with extended puzzles involving painful walking from one end of the map to the other.  Aside from the particularly grueling dungeon and the utter lack of promised side quests, Skyborn proved to be a short but delightful game.  I'll certainly be replaying it in the future to try different class combinations and fighting styles.
A fun, fairly short RPG.
Feels Just like a classic SNES Game honestly I just love it. All RPG fans should give this a play. Took me back to teh good old days of the RPG's. Great Job guys

I couldn't remove a selection and I couldn't make an intermediate selection so I went with yes.  I enjoyed playing the game for the most part.  The story may use a tried and true plot device, but it does contain a few twists that I, at least, didn't see coming.  The world is fairly small, but most of the areas are very diversified so it doesn't feel that way.  Also the smithing is a nice touch, though I would have liked to make higher quality armor as well.

My problem with the game was the combat balance.  For one I almost immediately turned the game up to hard.  This is something I almost never do as I generally like to keep combat just difficult enough that I keep interested without becoming a hassle.  On Normal there was absolutely no challenge.  For most random encounters that didn't change much on Hard.  Boss battles, came in two varities: 'What just wiped me in 2 seconds' or 'what did I just roll over.'  There are certain skills in the game (For you and your enemies) that are just ridiculously strong.  But if you don't use them, then battles just drag on because at least with how I was building characters (trying to emphasize +Str as much as I could!) only 1-2 of my characters ever did appreciable amounts of damage.  Also the character classes are very specialized. Only certain people dealt damage, and at times it really felt the only reason threat" existed was to give the tank something to do on his turn.

Overall Story is a +
date: game balance is a -.  Take your pick on which is more important to you."

reviewText:
Played through this in about six hours; in one sitting.  Why in one sitting, you ask?  Because I couldn't tear myself away!  The story here does a rather good job of telling itself during that six hours(which could be four or less if you're in a hurry).  It's a fairly nuanced tale with all the proper tragic hero tropes, plot twists and surprise endings, but it doesn't do a lot of padding to get there.
If you're looking for any kind of gameplay balance, do speed runs.  Otherwise this game is incredibly easy even on its hardest settings, although there is one battle you will never win ;).

All in all, for $7.49 (at half price) I felt like I got my money's worth and then some.  This is a rather well-polished RPGmaker gem that will leave you wanting more from this developer in the future!

Solid, enjoyable, well put-together game.

The game's difficulty on Normal is a bit too easy, although Hard mode presents a decent challenge, especially earlier on in the game (before you get access to the really OP debuffs).

Despite the RPG Maker feel that a lot of people seem to detest, Skyborn's a very polished package.  I noticed a couple small bugs and a couple typos, but that was it on the negatives.

I was able to play this with a controller, which was very appreciated.  I used a 3rd party knockoff Xbox360 controller, which didn't require any additional setup upon booting the game.  However, I was able to hit F1 in-game and remap the buttons to something more sensible, the defaults didn't make sense on my particular controller.

Dialogue was well-written, enjoyable, and fairly humorous.  Plot, while a bit short, was interesting and flowed well.  Combat system had a nice brisk pace, with good yet swift animations for attacks.

The leveling and itemization was a stand-out success, in my mind: armor is equippable by all characters, but if you weigh a character down beyond their carrying capacity, their speed drops off.  There are a few ways of increasing that capacity later in the game.  But that broad eligibility allows a much wider amount of equipment options for each character, as you can trade off weight between different slots to equip items you REALLY want.  The augment system is simple yet robust, offering another layer of customizibility to your characters.  Furthermore, there are two class up"s during the game
date: where you can upgrade each character to a new job class.  The game does a great job of explaining the options prior to selection
recommended: so you don't need to consult a third party resource for information.\n\nIt took me about 15 hours to complete the game
hoursPlayed: playing in hard mode and completing all optional content&bosses.  I'm a bit of a slow player
helpfulPercent: so most folks will probably take about 7-12 depending on difficulty and completeness.\n\nI don't think I'd pay the full $15 for this one due to its length
votesHelpful: but at sale prices it's a great purchase.\n\nEnjoy!"

reviewText: Nostalgia boner.

The devs of this game have bottled up the sheer joy and sense of wonder from the old school Final Fantasy games (before they became emo boy meets emo girl romances) and just gave us a fun, well written, wonderfully designed and beautifully scored RPG. Some tropes are followed and a little predictable but the additions of a fast crafting system and no random enounters makes the game a positive experience. It made me feel 15 again, staying up super late to play just a little longer. Although if you do it once with this game you'll probably finish it as I hear it averages about 8hrs play time, though I don't know what difficulty that is. Get it on sale for full value.
Overall great game. The final boss is a load of bull though. Literally impossible. I can't even put a dent in him.

My only complaint is that, for the quality of the game, it wasn't long enough... which is why I WILL be looking out for any more games by Dancing Dragon. No really, it's the best game of it's type that I've played to date!

Skyborn is a game that I initially expected to dislike, the early dialogue is really blunt exposition that occasionally resembles a flashback episode. The game continues to push you through scripted pieces about an evil race of winged people with early twists that move so fast I hardly remember them. If you've played these kind of games on super NES this is comfort food almost that's too comfortable as the harder fights are in a Colosseum, as very few fights in the main quest will challenge those who put ingots into their weapons.

Yet the game eventually won me over and cleansed my snickering black heart, the game's humor is gentle and devoid of overt references and while the writing remains blunt the complete lack of cynicism lowered my defenses and was even invested in what will happen to the girl from the sewers. There is such care into keeping your attention and making the environments rewarding to explore, there are no random battles and numerous hidden places where exp boosts hide, creepy barflies that offer you suspicious drinks, and even a constantly hungry lady.

For seven hours I played this and upgraded my swords and rivet guns, a bit short for those who miss 40 hour games  from the 90s but a not a second too long. The game not only is aware of the past it embraces those old games wholeheartedly like the most affectionate love letter.

Played through this in about six hours; in one sitting.  Why in one sitting, you ask?  Because I couldn't tear myself away!  The story here does a rather good job of telling itself during that six hours(which could be four or less if you're in a hurry).  It's a fairly nuanced tale with all the proper tragic hero tropes, plot twists and surprise endings, but it doesn't do a lot of padding to get there.
If you're looking for any kind of gameplay balance, do speed runs.  Otherwise this game is incredibly easy even on its hardest settings, although there is one battle you will never win ;).

All in all, for $7.49 (at half price) I felt like I got my money's worth and then some.  This is a rather well-polished RPGmaker gem that will leave you wanting more from this developer in the future!

Despite the RPG Maker feel that a lot of people seem to detest, Skyborn's a very polished package.  I noticed a couple small bugs and a couple typos, but that was it on the negatives.

I was able to play this with a controller, which was very appreciated.  I used a 3rd party knockoff Xbox360 controller, which didn't require any additional setup upon booting the game.  However, I was able to hit F1 in-game and remap the buttons to something more sensible, the defaults didn't make sense on my particular controller.

reviewText: All in all, you can play through it in about 6-7 hours, so not a long game. Nice story, moderately acceptable (if clicéd) characters. Item variety seems OK. Graphics-wise, I wish the ingame character-drawings got nearly the same attention as the one on the boxart. They are jarringly different. It has its own set of bugs (the most annoying is hiding  the enemy life bar about a second after it changes), but it is playable. There is also crafting that can get you some pretty nifty items.\n\nAll-in-all, nice, but short indie RPG. Not worth the 13€, but for $1 bundle, it was A-OK.
Really well made game, full of details and a nice story. Besides that, full of humour.\nThe game itself is easy and that makes the gameplay go smoothly. So it is an awesome choice for casual players.

I am an old school gamer and I played a tone of old style RPG games and this one really takes me back at least to the super Nintendo years. this game really has a lot to offer really good sound track. an unusual but interesting combat system. this game has a really solid story line and the dialogue is also quite good. most games like this have serious dialog issues and they sound corny or just silly so its nice to play a game that has a nice flow to it. The art work for this game is also very nice to look at, not professional mind you but still very good. The maps and out side world are pleasant with lots to look at but not filled with clutter.  this game offers a crafting system that on one hand is rewarding to find components to craft with, but unfortunately the crafting system leaves something to be desired. all in all this game has good balance the character roles are well defined. my mage is not a tank my tank is not a DPSer and I have options to develop my character classes the way I want to fit with my play style through class upgrades reminiscent of the original Final Fantasy games.  I felt the ending was a bit rushed and you can get through the story line rather fast so you wont be racking up 40+ hrs of game time on this one you might not even get half that. so I wish the game had been a bit longer with some more side quests to do or even a bit more towards the end.  I don't want to be down on this game just fair. I will add that this has been the most enjoyable game of its type I have played so far. great work!!!

So I just beat this game, took me about 5 hours because I spent half the time afk... No pause feature ftw, anyways... I enjoyed the game for the most part, I think that the combat system could use some work however, primarily the fact that it's more of a whoever can hit the hardest the fastest wins type system. I had taken the pure dark side of corwin and actually have to say minus the lacking of any revival it was really nice being able to never worry about health until you get to the insta killing foes(there were only such when you are undergeared, I didn't finish the colleseum, just enough for gear and such from the shops due to the tough guys, have to say they are stronger than anything you encounter after it...). The music was decently done, though I'd have liked some intense music during boss fights... And the end boss was a big let down...hell there is a tougher fight in the same area in the form of a reoccuring NPC who talks about food a lot(Forgot her name, couldn't even come close to beating her). Over all though I'd recommend this game purely for a quick hit it and quit it game, the main issue I had was that it looked like it was made on one of the RPG makers and as such lacks any real potential that a hand crafted game could have(odds are it may have been hand done, but just wasn't planned to be pushed further... either way it's still good) I'd love to see a sequal or what happens next, though I'll say that the story definately could of used some work, and chaska while I loved her design, her personality was poorly done... the others were at least somewhat respectable for their roles... I will add however that it's not worth $15 due to it's length...

reviewText: Just started this game. Seems a little too easy compared to the average JRPG, but at least it has a somewhat fresh battle system. I give it a 7/10.

This game was a very satisfying and quickly immersive new-age RPG. It had a feeling reminiscent of FF6 and Chrono Trigger for me, which was a big plus given my love of those games. The combat was quite addicting, and the different class choices, in addition to gear customization up the wazoo, made character progression very fulfilling.\n\nIt is a fairly short game (I did 95% of everything, and I clocked a little under 20 hrs in my playthrough), but I loved every minute of it. The only complaint I might make is the ending felt somewhat abrupt, and I definitey ended up feeling like I wanted more.

Fun SNES style JRPG
Enjoyable story. I shed a tear or two. I'm a softie.
Optional boss at end can be a bit difficult. For gear put puffin feathers on your armor to increase SPD. +4 metal ingots on weapons.

1st playthrough on hard I couldn't beat the optional boss so I did a 2nd replay.

Skyborn is a short RPGMaker-made game that's very good looking (in the japanese anime classical style) and has great music.  It exposes interracial and social classes conflicts in a steampunk-fantasy sort of environment. The story is good but the arcs of the characters' stories are not very complicated and there are no important choices to make or crossroads where several endings can develop.

Fights are not at every corner of an alley because you can visually choose (most of the times) if you fight enemies or you just ignore them. The story/fighting ratio is well balanced, but while some generic enemies are a piece of cake some bosses are a pain in the mouse's left button. By the way, while some enemies' design goes according to the world presented, some others seem to have been taken out of other very different projects.

Gameplay is easy either with a keyboard or with the mouse, but the UI both in the character menus and in battle is a little bit of a mess and if you pause the game for a long time you will have to re-learn almost everything. Fights are repetitive and turn-based and the special effects are not outstanding but acceptable. You can upgrade your characters' classes and abbilities but even then some of they are left behind while others grow.

I recommend Skyborn if you like classical J-turn-based-RPGs and you are not too exigent.

The game was a lot of fun with an engaging story. My only complaint is that, at only about ten hours, it's way too short for its genre (RPG). If there's a sequel or tie-in later on in the future, you better believe I'm going to buy it.

The story can be somewhat predictable while still being very good.  The dialogue is written extremely well and all of the characters stayed true to themselves throughout the game.  The combat has a lot of depth for a turn based game, the customization options for class ups and for equipment add a decent amount of replayability.  I really only had a difficult time with 1 boss battle during the game and if you abuse a certain item that fight becomes somewhat trivial,  Thus the difficulty of the game even on hard is not very high unless you don't understand how to min max your party.\n\nAll in all I would recomend this game.
Great game.I love stylish RPG games like those.10/10 would play again.

Only bad thing I can say about it is that it is relatively short. I did everything I could in the game and took my time. Took me 13-14 hours to finish, but you can easily finish in under 9. Also the equipment and upgrading system was sub par. You would have to switch back and forth menus and you had no way of comparing equipment you craft until you actually make it.

I recommend you play on hard mode if you want a challenge. Otherwise it's too easy.

Let me tldr my review: This game's story is one of the best I've encountered from an independent studio, and the mechanics itself work quite well. But my experience has not been a positive one. I may keep playing just to enjoy the story, but probably not on my pc if I do. My experience may not happen for everyone, but I can only speak for my experience.

For the rest of you.

I want to love this game. I do. I really do. But the design choices that have been made are pretty bad and the excuses made for them even moreso.

640X800 is not an acceptable visual resolution in 2015, or in 2014, or in 2013, or in fact any time in the past decade. To hard code it at that level seems almost preposterous. We can blame the system he used to craft this game all we and he wants, but I have played a good number of RPGmaker games and they all worked just fine in higher resolutions.

Going on isn't explaining, so let's explain. When I enter fullscreen mode, a good 1/6 of the screen becomes invisible. Unfortunately, it's the part of the screen where all the buttons are. This appears to be hardcoded. I have tried a number of solutions to make the screen fit into my monitor, and none have worked.

So I could play it in windowed mode? Yes, but windowed mode is not resizable. And I've not had much luck in moving it around the screen, either. More importantly, I don't like playing in windowed mode and I resent being told that is my only choice.

You may be asking. why is this a big deal? Well, it isn't, strawman. It is not a big deal. It is, however, enough of one. The market is full. Crowded to the brim with games as good or almost as good as this, many of them almost as well written or even better written. When it comes to things like this, everyone decides their own place to draw the line, and this is mine.

I already own the game, I wouldn't return it if I could, and I wish the developers all the best in their future endeavours. But I cannot recommend this game.

Only bad thing I can say about it is that it is relatively short. I did everything I could in the game and took my time. Took me 13-14 hours to finish, but you can easily finish in under 9. Also the equipment and upgrading system was sub par. You would have to switch back and forth menus and you had no way of comparing equipment you craft until you actually make it.

I recommend you play on hard mode if you want a challenge. Otherwise it's too easy.
Really loved playing this game, wonderfull story that just dazzles you and make you want to know more and more, not to mention the characters\n\n

An interesting and compelling game from start to finish. Skyborn is an RPG-Maker made game with it's unique style, the environments throught the game are very well detailed which just goes to show how much work and time the developers put on it.
The game is very story-driven so if you're not so much into story and more into constant action this isn't the game for you. The characters are well designed, each one having it's unique objective and background explained in the game through constant flashbacks, which in turn translates into a nice storytelling. Skyborn features a crafting system which allows you to craft armors and weapons from ores you pick along the way and an augment system which allows you to enchant them, the system itself is really simple but at the same time really addicting and you'll find yourself more often than not looking at every wall in search of ores (I know I did!).
Not all is good about the game however. Some changes to the battle system for example (which still features some RPG-Maker standard sprites and grid system) could have been explored way better. The mouse feature, here strangely introduced, also doesn't make much sense for this kind of game, you'll find out that using the mouse will only make things more complicated and unnatural, luckily the developers added an option in the menu to toggle on/off the mouse feature. Achievements for Steam also not supported which is actually a real bummer since you have so much to achieve in this game! Oh well :)
Overall a great game with over 12+ hours of content to explore, be it sidequesting, following the main story line or crafting in your free time. Congratulations to the developers. 8/10

Very good Game, classic art style, recommend playing on hard, at least in early levels as it is easy to have a healer heal through most of the enemies damage and generate no threat. Combat is unique, plenty of enemy types from the get go and compelling storyline. My only complaint is the lack of visual settings in the game, such as resolution.
A really nice story and the click to move and attack has a satisfaction of its own.
good plot! in the rpg world, a good plot is most appreciated. :)

I found the combat to be a bit tedious after a while, but the story was very engaging, and the characters were interesting and worth getting to know. Since it's not a particularly long game, it doesn't last too much past the point where the combat has become boring, meaning that it's never really a grind to get through. Really good, very much enjoyed it-kinda piqued my interest in jrpgs!

Surprinsingly enjoyable. I did not think that I would like an rpgmaker game as much as this one, especially since it's turn-based. I got the game when it was free, so wait for a sale.

Awesome points:
There is a lot of freedom in this game. You can do whatever you want, whenever you want. There's crafting, an arena, collectables and tons of places to explore.
The story is pretty well written. The characters were memorable. Their individual storylines were awesome to read and wove into the main story really well. (Personally, Alda's is my favourite storyline. Especially the end.)
It plays a little like a visual novel. With fighting and exploring. Not bad. Lots of reading.
Downsides include:
Lack of map, extremely easy to get lost. I would love to have a minimap or something to show locations.
Very little tooltips. Though, that may be an upside as well? It takes a bit of experimenting and trial & error to work out exactly what's going on in the game.
Mouse interaction was not smooth. It was difficult to navigate the inventory. Mouse control over the menus was pretty clunky as well.
Quest menu sucked. Sometimes the writing at the end would be cut off and it was impossible to read the last couple of steps. Sometimes I forgot who I had to return my sidequest to, as the place wasn't stated. Ended up running around for half an hour talking to everyone I came across.
If you can deal with the downsides, the game is enjoyable and worth the time.
Fun for a while, then the balancing issues kick in. Then it just gets ridiculous.

Brings back my memories of the old classic games I've played. Great game, got it for free. Shoutout to PC Gamer for posting a notification on Facebook! Thx a lot!\n\n8/10 If there is more clues on where to go, like a compass or something that be great because I'm having trouble finding my way around.

Well, I got this game free through PC Gamer and I find myself sad that I didn't contribute to the makers.  RPG Maker or not, this is one of the better RPGs I've played in a while.

While it might be your standard SNES-esque RPG, it still hits all the right notes.  The main character is as bad  as she wants to be, the style works, the classes are interesting enough; all in all it's left me impressed.

If you're longing for that old-style RPG and don't want to boot up an emulator and replay a classic, give this one a shot.  You may well find yourself very surprised.

Ahh...the age of releasing quick games via RPG Maker.

I must say, I used to fiddle around with the RPG Maker games on console for Playstation (original) and never could craft something quite as beautiful as this game right here. Level design is refreshing, and of a very cool art style. Aside from the hero's avatars being selected from stock images, the story is very present here and quickly wraps you in.

If you are a fan of classic RPG or JRPG games such as Chrono Trigger, the original Final Fantasy series, and turn based combat; this is a nice addition for your collection. The story is well written, with a couple twists! Check it out, this game doesn't actually suck.

LOVED This game. It took me about 8 hours to clear (I played in offline mode on my laptop for half of it). The combat is balanced and the characters are interesting and all useful in their own way. All characters are customizable from picking which skills they learn, to choosing equipment, to finally choosing which item/buff to apply to each piece of equipment. Building up my characters was the funnest part. The combat is interesting. It has a threat system where enemies focus on the party members doing the flashiest moves. Exploring the game world is vastly rewarding and encouraged. Not only do you find great gear, but you can find experience points by exploring. The game also has additional side content that I didnt complete in my 8 hour playthrough. This includes, a fighting arena, a side dungeon to explore, and finding a deck of cards that has been scattered across the land. My only complaint is that the weapon/armor crafting system in this game seems tacked on and forgettable. The items you can craft are limited and you usually have them by the time you can craft them anyway. Having said that, this is a game that no RPG fan should miss out on. 9.5/10

(This review is based on my main experiences with just the first 5 minutes of the game. I will say dont take my own opinion at this point in time look at some other peoples reviews to get a better opinion of the game or look at some gameplay online.)

The game has some good music but it can be forgettable at times and somehow in my opinion it feels like theres no type of story astablished in the first five minutes even if there is a lot of dialogue in the start of the game but along with this i can also see theres no real character introductions as well it kinda makes the player to have to go on a guess at the start to figure out the personalities of each person to potentially see any development later on in the game.

The gameplay is your generic rpg gameplay you walk around and talk to people do some quests and fight some monsters. (I think this is mainly due to being used in the rpgmaker engine what seems like that could be a limitation) The Battle gameplay is somewhat interesting with having the threat meter where enemys will focus on the highest threat hero on their turn whats a very interesting mechanic what forces you to actually defend your best hero in the party and its pulled off well (in the fights i have experienced so far)

The game does seem pretty good from what i have experienced so far but theres also a factor what makes me not want to play the game again and i cant say i have a genuine oppinion untill i have completed the game so i would say dont go off from what i say look at some more reviews before getting a buyers opinion.

I would recommend this game to any rpg fan but not to any newcomers to the rpg genre.

Skyborn review:

Skyborn is a small rpg game (took me 8 hours to complete, there are some undone side missions, I think)

Basically you are a mechanic girl who's life gets turned upside down and a whole lot of ♥♥♥♥ happens... There is another race called the Skyborn who are opressing humans and half skyborn half humans. You eventually... <spoiler!!>

Well, just play the damn game, its well worth it if you are in to this genre.

Pros:

Saturated content, like all good RPGs should have.

This game is amazing, so many things to do, so many secrets and areas to go to.

Good characters and story (the jungle mission was freaking amazing, learning the past of another character and some other things. I was like holy ♥♥♥♥ I just had fun).

Amazing soundtrack. Everything just flows.

AMAZING character customization, it beats many other full scale free rpg's (mmorpg's too for that matter) that I've played. You can improve, augment, create and do many more things with your items. And too many extra things to name.

A lot of side missions that the npc's give (they give hints on secrets too!)

And not to mention the npc's all have their little attitudes and get you into the lore of the game. I reccomend for having more immersion, take your time and read all the dialogue (thats what these older top down games are about guys!!!)

Cons:

Nothing in particular, it's an rpgmaker game, so expect dated graphics, but this game isn't for gamers that care about that sort of thing.

Also, this game is not for people new to the genre (it is, but some whole game quests like looking for the playing cards will get messed up if you dont literally walk on every inch of the world in every mission, or you need to go back later).

End result: 9/10, not for everyone but it nails the content in every way possible for this genre.

P.S: I got this as a free key from pcgamer, IDK if it's still available.

REVIEW:


While very skeptical when first acquiring the game, I decided to give it a go and was not let down. Very similar to the RPGs of old, those seeking to re-enter that kind of world won't be let down either!


Story - While perhaps not the most deep story ever written for an RPG, it certainly wasn't bad. It had, to me, plenty of depth for the length of the game as a whole. It also had a good amount of all the story elements one would look for. While it wasn't necessarily evoking particular emotions for me, it might for you. I give the story a solid 8/10.

Audio - The sound track for the game was particularly good, which caught me by surprise. I never found myself thinking Man
date: this track is annoying..." and muting the sound. Do you remember how Chrono Trigger's amazing sound track really set the atmosphere for the different areas in the game? Skyborn does the same. I give the audio a well-deserved 10/10.\n\nVisual - Again
recommended: this game takes me back. There's nostalgia everywhere. With that in mind
hoursPlayed: the graphics
helpfulPercent: artwork
votesHelpful: etc. don't let down. Very pleasing to the eye
votesTotal: in every area of the game. I can't think of an area or situation in which I thought something looked like it could have been done better. The different artwork and visual effects all fit in their respective areas
votesFunny: and paired with the music really brought everything together. Visuals get a 10/10 from me as well.\n\nGameplay - Here's where I get really nitpicky. There are a few things here that could be done better
commentsCount: so I'll list them in no particular order:\n\n1. Mouse controls - During battles (which were handled great! no random battles!)
column16: I found myself accidentally clicking on an option I didn't intend to. For example
column17: a few times I misclicked and ended up "Guarding" on a turn that I needed to do something else... because the curser was "stuck" on the icon beside it. It's kind of hard to describe
column18: but if you're careful it isn't too much of an issue.\n\n2. DEBUFFS - This one is a major gripe for me. You can track buffs/debuffs on your party with a visual alert in the upper-right corner of their portraits. Enemy debuffs
column20: you have to deliberately watch for "-DebuffName" to appear in text near the bottom of their image when it wears off. This can be very
column21: very debilitating to your plans if a necessary debuff (Majesty
column22: for example) falls off without you noticing it... which is very possible if the enemy uses some form of buff that either removes it
column23: or grants them all kinds of buffs and your debuffs just happen to fall on off that turn anyway.\n\nFor future games
column24: I would most definitely recommend some kind of visual aid for enemy debuffs
column26: there was really only a few situaions where it was of dire importance that I had to keep track of enemy debuffs
column27: but it meant a party wipe (no joke) if one fell off and I didn't notice.\n\n3. Difficulty - Not necessarily a gripe
column28: but also not necessarily something I can comment on entirely. The game has 3 different combat difficulties: Easy
column30: and Hard. I played through the game on Normal
column31: and found it to be far too easy in parts. I haven't played through it again on Hard
column32: so I can't comment on Hard mode; however
column33: given the resources available to you
column34: "Normal" difficulty becomes a little too easy. (Except for a few parts
column35: but I'm not going to spoil anything here.)\n\n4. Game Length - I put in 15 hours to this game before completion. This is with about a 99% completion rate. While 15 hours is a far cry from the 50 to 60 hours a game like Chrono Trigger or Final Fantasy 3 (6) had with a similar completion rate
column36: it was pretty generous for this game. Also note that about 4 of those hours are me back-tracking in the damned forest.\n\nWith those small issues in mind
column37: I'm going with an 8/10 on the gameplay. It had everything I liked
column39:
but also a few issues I feel could have been handled better.

Over all
column41: and a high recommendation to anyone who grew up with the great RPGs from the SNES era

I got this game for free on a site  that I used to buy Steam Games cheaper so here are my Good, Mediocore and Bad. I am an avid RPG/JRPG game who used to play Final Fantasy and Chrono Trigger when I was younger and still play them to this day sometimes.


Good:
Characters - I actually like these characters, great backstory wished they introduced characters more clearly than rushing them.

Mediocore:

Music - It's ok

Story - It's kinda messed up as you get thrown into different scenarios and I partially have no idea whats going on

Artwork- Although decent but kinda plain

Battle System- Quite nice of adding in a Threat system. Thinking of my way through of how to deal with my enemies but that was quickly overlooked aka get the guy who has the most hp finishing off the enemy so he takes damaged while keeping the damaged dealing with hp sustain and weakening the games. Also my characters get KO in battle unfairly: Gouge- Me: Chance of blinding a person with an attack. Monster: Chance of Blinding the enemy with a chance of KO.

Bad:

ITS FEELS SHORT - I take my sweet as time when learning a new RPG game but dam the short feeling is strong here.

CURRENCY IS REDUNDANT- You can basically survive off the items that you find instead of buying them, there are plenty HP/MP restore points in the game.

Boss Battles: Feeling extremely boring and easy heck Yakra gave me a harder time than the first couple bosses combined.



In short if you were buying this game don't buy it at full price its not worth it.

I honestly had my doubts when it came to another RPG Maker game. I waited until it came packaged in a bundle sale, and I actually feel I made away like a thief for the price I paid.\n\nI've been playing RPGs since the early-mid eras of the Final Fantasy (and other 8-16-bit console games), Wizardry, and Might and Magic games, as well as a fair share of real" indie RPGs like the Avernum series
hoursPlayed: Deadly Sin 2

I had no real qualms about this game.

You can honestly play the game how you want:
- No random encounters
- level-ups give you very few stats in comparison to equipment
votesTotal: i.e. you can skip as much as you can sneak past\n- powerful equipment is found via exploration
votesFunny: crafting
commentsCount:
or the optional dungeons and colosseum battles
- crafting is actually useful and you find all the materials you need during normal gameplay: no random drops or farming!
- many of my "expert" tier craft items were actually used instead of my "unique" endgame loot
- powerful augment items and accessories to further customize the roles of your equipment and characters
- a number of class changes that include skill and stat choices for all characters
- incentives for exploration: rare equipment

and experience bonuses

Skyborn is a turn-based RPG in the vein of old-school RPGs like Final Fantasy. You control a band of characters that are trying to save the world from the tyrannical yadda yadda yadda, you know the drill. It was all made with RPG Maker, but don't let that turn you off -- I'd say it's worth a look.\n\nI found this game rather charming. While the plot, music, and graphics aren't the newest and shiniest things ever, everything is good quality and holds together well enough for me to enjoy playing through it -- I even want to run through it again later. There are moments between characters to establish them more beyond insert hero person here"
date: and the world combines steampunk with a more standard fantasy setting in a way that's enjoyable
recommended: with more going on than is apparent at first. While there might not be a whole lot more to do than just the main story
hoursPlayed: there are some sidequests for players who poke around looking for extra treasure
voteText: and there's a crafting/augment system for people who want to micromanage their equipment a bit more.\n\nThe battle system is pretty fun to work with -- each character has a threat level that rises as they do damage
helpfulPercent: and whoever has the highest threat will be soaking up most of the attacks. The key is to make sure the tankiest character in your group keeps their threat level the highest (easier said than done
votesHelpful: at times!)
votesTotal: and I feel it works fairly well. Most fights are fairly simple
votesFunny: though there are some trickier fights later in the game -- the final boss and bonus boss in particular are pretty darn hard to deal with.\n\nAll in all
commentsCount: I'd say give this game a try if a charming little steampunk/fantasy turn-based RPG with fun characters and a neat battle system sounds interesting to you."

I got this game for free so I wasn't expecting much.  Overall I had a positive experience.  For a game that is made with rpg maker this really isn't a bad game.  Obviously there are all kinds of rpgs you could find that are better than this game.  This game has some rough edges for sure, but it has a solid storyline so it is easy to look past some of the games flaws such as the combat system could have been done better.  If you play this on hard mode some of the bosses will give you quite a challenge.

I don't actually remember buying this game, and when I found it in my library and played it I was pleasantly surpised. It's surprisingly well written, and the gameplay is well balanced.

The gameplay is far from revolutionary, apart from the 'threat'-mechanic which I've never seen before, but works really well and is nicely streamlined. It's well balanced, but some areas lack a little polish. That's acceptable since it was made by a small team, and it never breaks the game in any way. The soundtrack is nothing revolutionary either, but at least it's nice music and it fits the settings it plays in.

The main characters are well written and realtable. The game succeeded in making me like the heroes and at least disliking the villains enough that I agree with the ultimate goal the heroes are working towards. The story is not overly dramatic, it doesn't try desperately to be funny all the time, and it's not all grim or lighthearted. It introduces characters at a good pace and gives them space to develop over time.

This game is like a good fantasy-steampunk book, with monster slaying in between every chapter. The game succeedes in really feeling like an adventure, but it never loses sight of the end goal.

This game is exteemely fun I have just started, and I am enjoying it so much. The turn base combat is great and thoughtful, all the controls and menus are intuitive and the art and style of the game is quite good. However i wished that all characters had an animation when they speak and sometimes the music just stops and there is no audio, getting rid of all immersion. Other than that the game is fun and if you are thinking of getting it get it.\nI give it a solid 7.8

This game is really a beauty! Filled with beautiful art, interesting characters and a story that keeps you going without boredom, it gets my full recommendation. It is well balanced, giving you just the right challenge throughout the whole game (although the final battles were long rather than challenging, it doesn't really negate the rest of the game's balance).

If you're looking for an RPG game with a different and interesting story, this is definitely for you.

There might be three tiny complaints: the dungeons did seem quite similar to each other, the sidequest fanatic in me didn't quite get its hunger satisfied and most importantly - I want more! Give me a sequel, please! I want to dive even further into the universe. I am definitely going to be on the lookout for any other games by this publisher.

i found having fun playing this games, the story between human, skyborn, and half-breed makes a conflict and recommended to RPG Fan

Overall, this a very good game. Although it's got a few problems, these can easily be overlooked.

The Good
________

Story: The plot is engaging, with a lot of neat moments where you feel emotionally compelled to keep playing. If you're playing an RPG, you NEED a good story to compel play. At the beginning you're forced to betray/trick someone to save your family. Who isn't willing to do everything they can for their family?

BGM: The music is very atmospheric, usually fitting situation well and sound very much like music from games on the PS2 or XBOX. The music is in stereo as well, but this is less useful than stereo sound effects.

Graphics: The visuals are reminiscent of the 16-bit era of console gaming in terms of color and the sprite drawing methods common on the NES/SNES, Genisis, and PSX. More than anything else I'm reminded of the original Dragon Warrior (Dragon Quest) 1-3 and Breath of Fire 1 and 2 games in regards to gameplay, with a Town overmap, a menu overmap, dungeon overmap, and world overmap, along with the turn based combat system. Also, when going full screen on my monitor the game doesn't look bad, but doesn't have 1080p support running at 640x480, so probably won't work well with or look good on TVs.

The Bad
_______

Sound: The sound effects are very subpar by todays standards, but equal to if not better than those of the 16-bit and 32-bit console era. The sound effects do not seem to be in stereo.

Sound/Visual Timing: Often sound effects, i.e. attacks in combat, will occur just before the visual identifier does. This tends to throw the combat immersion right out the window for me, but it's not overly horrible, and certainly doesn't break the game.

The Ugly
_______

Controls: X-input controllers, that is to say anything resembling the Xbox 360 controller, have wonky button command registers, with Menu/Cancel being assigned to B and Interact/Accept being assinged to X, and Previous Page/Next Page being assigned to Back/Start respectively. Worse, still, there is no way to reassign them in game.

The controls for D-input controllers, resembling Playstation 2 or 3 controllers, is much better with Menu/Cancel being assigned to X and Interact/Accept being assigned to O, and Previous Page/Next Page assigned to L2/R2 respectively. The Logitech F series controllers 310, 510, and 710, are able to switch between these input types, so I recommend using D-input with them. I've tested PS3, Wireless Xbox 360 for Windows, and Logitech F510 controllers with this game.

Mouse and keyboard are simple enough with the avatar attempting to take the shortest route to where you click on the overmaps or moving in the cardinals with the arrow keys, and clicking on commands and enemies in combat or selecting them with left/right arrow keys and pressing enter.
lll

After reading the synopsis for this game, I was unsure of what to expect. The story sounded dull, but I was looking for a new RPG to play, so I gave Skyborn a chance. In the end, I am very glad I made that decision.

I was enthralled by the lovable characters, the gorgeous environments, and a surprisingly endearing story. Skyborn also utilizes a targeting system called “Threat Levels”, which results in very satisfying battles.

Although the game can be completed in a short amount of time, in my opinion, it is worth the full price.  If you are looking for an excellent turn-based RPG to play, I highly recommend this game.

Hands down the best RPG ever made with RPG Maker. Love the steampunk setting and the characters have personality. They do feel like actual people. Exploration is there and quests are great. Classic turn based battles are the juice of the game and are fast and fun. If you like Final Fantasy style RPG`s with a more european setting this is the game to go.
the story good

I've played many RPG maker crafted games and I've got to say this one makes it into the top five. The music and artwork are both amazing. The story is also very interesting and kept my attention throughout the whole game. In fact, it was so good that I felt the need to play the game again once I had finished it. There is some flexibility is choosing the class of the character, which is quite uncommon in story based RPG maker games. The dialouge is well written too. I can't say there much of a downside to it other than the fact that it's shorter than I'd like it to be but all in all, it's a wonderul game that I'd recommend to all RPG players.

All these make this game a well worth experience.

reviewText:
Skyborn is a short RPGMaker-made game that's very good looking (in the japanese anime classical style) and has great music.  It exposes interracial and social classes conflicts in a steampunk-fantasy sort of environment. The story is good but the arcs of the characters' stories are not very complicated and there are no important choices to make or crossroads where several endings can develop.

Fights are not at every corner of an alley because you can visually choose (most of the times) if you fight enemies or you just ignore them. The story/fighting ratio is well balanced, but while some generic enemies are a piece of cake some bosses are a pain in the mouse's left button. By the way, while some enemies' design goes according to the world presented, some others seem to have been taken out of other very different projects.

Gameplay is easy either with a keyboard or with the mouse, but the UI both in the character menus and in battle is a little bit of a mess and if you pause the game for a long time you will have to re-learn almost everything. Fights are repetitive and turn-based and the special effects are not outstanding but acceptable. You can upgrade your characters' classes and abbilities but even then some of they are left behind while others grow.

I recommend Skyborn if you like classical J-turn-based-RPGs and you are not too exigent.

Fun SNES style JRPG

This game was a very satisfying and quickly immersive new-age RPG. It had a feeling reminiscent of FF6 and Chrono Trigger for me, which was a big plus given my love of those games. The combat was quite addicting, and the different class choices, in addition to gear customization up the wazoo, made character progression very fulfilling.\n\nIt is a fairly short game (I did 95% of everything, and I clocked a little under 20 hrs in my playthrough), but I loved every minute of it. The only complaint I might make is the ending felt somewhat abrupt, and I definitey ended up feeling like I wanted more.

Incredibly great RPG maker game. It is very well made, and it guides you along the right path without it feeling you are being hand-held at all. It also does not get overly complex or confusing which is well designed.\n\nOverall, it is a incredible standard for an RPG Maker game.

Skyborn........ where to begin. I completed this rpg in about 15 hours and I must say it was well worth it. But as usual, I like to give my likes and dislikes with every review so let's begin.

Likes:
1. Compelling story, truly an innocative piece. The whole story surrounding skyborn is enthralling and worth discovery the aspects of what, how and when did they came to be.
2. Characters are well thought out and utterly enjoying, had a few laughs and lead protanganist stoood out quite clearly among the others, however I must say all contributed to making the game enjoyable.
3. Battle system is damn good for an RPG such as this, developers got this down. Skills were on point for each character and it was nice that they thought of an upgrade system as well.
4. Augmenting system was verry good, love that aspect. did not use much of the actual making thing part of the game, but that was also well done.
5. Grapppphics, the graphics of the game is astounding, this is the first 2D..I think, rpg with such beautiful graphics I was amazed. Cleaan and not overbearing.

Seee basicallly, a recommended game from all of these points. But on to dislikes.
1. Sometimes there was some kinda lag or drag...like a fps thing. I am rather confused why this happens since it requires limited specs to run.
2. Difficulty, yes I played it on hard, so why the hell am I complaining if I got my ♥♥♥ handed to me. Welll....I defeated MOST of the bosses on hard, but the thing is once you defeat a monster, they dont respawn so you basically have a limited level cap from what exp points you gather. So the question is, how on earth I am suppose to beat something when you go from 1 to 1000 in the gap between one battle to the next. NUH MEK NO SENSE TO ME. But I digress I changed the difficulty in 4 instances because of this.
3. Why no respawn of monsters,if you lack the necessary level to win then it would make sense to level up. Thats rpg, I dont like turing down the difficulty just to progress in the story, and YES I TRIED, and it impossibru.
4. What elsse.... could use just a little more sidequest, think it was only 2. Could have improvise more and still not compromise the quality of the game.

Overall pretty good, I recommended...ooh wait yes.
5. The price of this game is not worth 14.99 it is marketed for. Should have been priced waaay lower. Yes it is well planned and so, but the value does not equate the experience. But I bought it for maybe $6.99 while on sale.. and I think that is more deserving. But then again, I from Jamaiaca, wher my dollar is quite devalued and so it is hard to fork out soo much money for an rpg as this. But then maybe mi cheap, who knows...hhappy playing folks.

Skyborn is probably the best RPGMaker game in the market, it is a fun RPG with lovely visuals and a great story that will keep you motivated until the end.

Pros:
Lovely textures and character drawings.
Well made Steampunk world with an interesting society.
Unforgettable cast of characters.
Nice, fitting soundtrack.
A great story that makes the game more enjoyable.
Cons:
The game is short, after 8.5 hrs I've finished the main story. This has a good side, you barely have to do any grinding so all your time in the game will be enjoyable.
Lack of secondary quests, the game is made towards the main story, I only found 2 secondary quests along the way.
The game resolution is locked to 640x480 so I had to play the whole thing on a small window on my 1080p monitor. (You can play it on fullscreen mode but if your monitor is 16:9 it will look stretched)
Overall I really enjoyed my experience with Skyborn and would definitely recommend it, specially if you can get it on sale.
It's an ok game, the story is pretty nice, but it's also very short of a storyline, and would have been better if the game was longer.\n\nI rate it 3.5/5

reviewText:
An interesting and compelling game from start to finish. Skyborn is an RPG-Maker made game with it's unique style, the environments throught the game are very well detailed which just goes to show how much work and time the developers put on it.
The game is very story-driven so if you're not so much into story and more into constant action this isn't the game for you. The characters are well designed, each one having it's unique objective and background explained in the game through constant flashbacks, which in turn translates into a nice storytelling. Skyborn features a crafting system which allows you to craft armors and weapons from ores you pick along the way and an augment system which allows you to enchant them, the system itself is really simple but at the same time really addicting and you'll find yourself more often than not looking at every wall in search of ores (I know I did!).
Not all is good about the game however. Some changes to the battle system for example (which still features some RPG-Maker standard sprites and grid system) could have been explored way better. The mouse feature, here strangely introduced, also doesn't make much sense for this kind of game, you'll find out that using the mouse will only make things more complicated and unnatural, luckily the developers added an option in the menu to toggle on/off the mouse feature. Achievements for Steam also not supported which is actually a real bummer since you have so much to achieve in this game! Oh well :)
Overall a great game with over 12+ hours of content to explore, be it sidequesting, following the main story line or crafting in your free time. Congratulations to the developers. 8/10

Skyborn is an RPG maker game that tell the story of Claret and her adventure in a steampunk setting.

Positives:

- Good artworks/sprites.
- Great world atmosphere.
- GUI is clean and well done.

So-so:
- Story is average, nothing too special.
- Characters did not hold my interest too much.
- Dialogues could be improved upon.

Negatives:
- Difficulty is imbalance for normal, it's a bit too hard.
- Combat feels too plain, not enough variety.
- Enemies lack diversity.
- Crafting should be fleshed out more.
- Small visual glitches here and there (Sunray still appears after re-entering cave).
- At $14.99, it's pricey.

This game is good when it wants to start I, I downloaded this game hoping to just start it up and play only to be stopped in my tracks by a black screen, I couldnt exit out of the screen not matter what I did, I had to turn the Computer off and back on just to try and play this game and this tends to happen a lot whenever I boot the game. I should be able to Play the game without worrying about the game breaking on me, this needs to be fixed asap as it is a game breaking bug that can get very irritating, so until its fixed, its a no from me

A story of rebellion against an unjust dictator(s), of human integrity, and of magic vs technology.  There's also a random chick who threatens, emptily, to eat you but never tries.  Unless you let her (but for real, why was she in the game)!

You play as Claret, a mechanic in the upper level of human society who repairs airships and makes the occasional automaton who can beep.  She somehow understands perfectly because reasons.  In her life is her brother and some random dude.  Her brother ends up being an awful guy (for reasons you'll learn five minutes in), but only for the first 10 minutes.  After wards, he changes into a damsel in distress and then we forget he exists.  If you don't have character art/portraits, then no one cares about you.  Welcome to video games.

The game play is typical old school RPG affair: you go to various lands; a desert, a volcano (that has surprising soothing music), a forest, ruins, and a multi-layered, caste style city.  You meet various people from all background, five of which are usable in combat, and then save the world.

Combat is a bit different than many games.  For the first half it's, arguably, optional.  You can find shining dots across the map and use that to level-up which give more exp than the actual monsters (only early on).  They're pretty easy to see to don't worry about missing any, besides, there's always the actual combat system to level up on.  Once you get all five characters, the dots effectiveness diminishes and killing monsters starts to be rewarding.  Fortunately, the battles can be fun.

Each character has a set of skills they learn, and that depend on their role in your party and the class you choose from.  At several points in the game, you have the option (meaning it's also optional) to upgrade character classes and learn new skills and passively upgrade stats.

Here's the kicker, though.  All of the skills are useful through out all of the game.  We've all played games where the earliest skills becomes obsolete about 10 minutes after learning it but Skyborn isn't one of those games.  That level 1 skill is still useful throughout the entire game or, at the very least, becomes a bridge to the more powerful, expensive, skills learned later in the game.  This is especially true for the non-magical characters who use energy (EN) to attack.  These characters gain EN when using basic attacks, or 0 EN skills, and release the EN when using the more powerful skills.  Buff/debuffs are one or two of a kind and are useful at all portions.  There is also a threat system that works similar to MMORPGS where, whoever has the most threat, gets punched in the face.  There is a bar that says who has what and is only relevant to enemy parties.  You can still attack whoever.

You also have the option to play each character in a variety of ways.  Do you want your mage to do damage with in-hands or with their spells?  Do you one character to be the buff/debuff character or the straight DPS?  Which character do you want to the tank?  Even the gear add to this.  Late game, there are multiple options for equipment for each character.  Some raise INT to do more damage with skills, some raise STR to do more with in-hands.  There are some limitations but there are freedoms not seen often in Skyborn.  *Keep in mind, I was playing on easy mode.  Apparently, hard has more set restrictions.

Characters are not on-screen in combat but the enemy sprites are.  Sadly, there is no animation but animation is hard and expensive for a small 2-3 people company.  Spell effects do exist and most are 32-bit pretty so there's something to look at while you shoot a “totally not a manticore” in the face.  There are no random battles and each enemy cluster is visible on the screen and only enters combat when it touches you.

The characters all have a definite personality and the developers did of a good job of trying to get you to emphasize with them.  There's the strong, independent female lead, the rich guy who actually just wants to be the hero, the good natured girl-beast who has been treated like an outcast, the sick of being pushed around mage, and the always questioning “superior race”.  When one character can no longer do a certain “thing” at the end of game, you feel bad.  When you find about the final fate of those captives, you're shocked and disgusted.  I was torn during the middle of the game when faced with the moral dilemma.  Alas, this is a liner game so the moral dilemma didn't fall into my hands but was played out as it did.

The game boosts an original soundtrack that is pretty good.  Nothing spectacular but nothing ruins the mood.  It's all very relaxing and worth listening to once or twice.  I'd get into specifics but I'm a bad musician and everyone has their own tastes so here's some streamable links so you can decide on your own:

Spotift Web Player[open.spotify.com]
iTunes[itunes.apple.com]

Art Work is pretty.  I'm not familiar with RPGMaker so I can't say how much of it has been over saturated in it's games.  Typical retro style; look at the screenshots.

Overall, Skyborn was a fun experience and, since the game is often on sale, is worth the money spent and time “wasted”.  I got 16 hours out of it and I've seen the game sell for a few bucks USD and it's worth it on sale.

Random high number / asinine equal or greater number

Growing up, the first RPG I ever played was Dragon Warrior on the NES, then it was Zelda, then between the NES and SNES I played the Final Fantasies, etc.  JRPGs were a genre I loved, even if I didn't really know the genre name back then.  I haven't played a JRPG-ish type of game since Albert Odyssey on the Sega Saturn back in the mid 90's honestly, so when I saw Skyborn pop up, I was intrigued.

I was hopeful that Skyborn would capture that spirit and feel that made me fall in love with the genre (but not rely on nostalgia).  My expectations were met and exceeded.  This is a fantastic JRPG game that has all the elements that make the genre great.  The story is fantastic, the battle system is tight, the graphics are clear and crisp and the musical score is extremely well done.

Another thing I enjoy here are that there are elements of random turn-based battles, but it's not random at all.  Enemies walk on paths that you can somewhat predict.  If you engage an enemy, you battle.  If you avoid the enemy, you don't.  There are certain narrow walkways where it would be hard to avoid an enemy, but honestly, you could probably play the entire game with only accidentally engaging a few enemies.  Or, you can choose to engage all enemies.  I love this option, because you still get plenty of fighting time, but you have a say in exactly when you'll be battling.

The end result is a 8 hour (if you play just to win) to probably 15 hour (if you do all the quests and explore everywhere) JRPG that anyone will love who is a fan of the genre.

While the plot, music, and graphics aren't the newest and shiniest things ever, everything is good quality and holds together well enough for me to enjoy playing through it -- I even want to run through it again later. had a fun time playing the game, I just saw the ending.

I thought I can play the game after watching the ending, but it wasn't. So I cannot do sidequests or colloseum, cause the game is saved at the final battle and I cannot get out of it. I should restart the whole story to do other things. That sucks.
Story was nice, battle was so-so, I'm addicted to Claret, and I cannot play as Claret the flying mechanic because that's only in the epilogue.

summary thingy
Everything was nice, but I would have liked it if you can play the game even after you saw the ending like in pokemon or something.

reviewText: Nice little RPG. The story was compelling and art was very well done. Definitely worth a play-through.

I am now a couple of hours into this game, and I am pleasantly surprised. All too often, I play RPG Maker games that look good, but really seem amateurish. So far, it seems like of the best RPG maker games I've seen. The story seems to be setting up nicely, the game play is pretty good, and it seems to have a level of polish above many other RPG maker games. I'm looking forward to playing it through. I've also got to say that the music is great for an RPG maker game.

If you like story-rich JRPGs, Skyborn is the game for you!

The characters all have real personalities, the story is compelling, and the dialogue is engaging. On top of all that, the gameplay is among the best you can find in the RPGMaker world.

I would recommend this game to any fan of RPGs!

I hate JRPGs, Final Fantasy VII included, but I liked this one anyway! Kudos to the devs.

Really loved playing through this game! The art style was just brilliant and brought back fond memories of Golden Sun and the older Final Fantasy games. The story was rich and exciting throughout the whole game. With also a good deal of humor mixed in! Would absolutely recommend for anyone into this type of game.
